description:
Oh man. LOADS of baked goods, all of them looking inviting and displayed to overflowing in baskets.
I had a raspberry and lemon curd scone and a blueberry muffin. I always get things I can share with my dog. He ate most of my haul but that is the way it goes in my house. It's the Dog Owner Diet for chumps with dogs!
That raspberry and lemon scone is worth the trip alone.
Counter help was friendly and happy. 
Parking was tricky but doable. 
Go. You won't regret it.
author: Lynne B.

description:
I have been reviewing bakeries recently and all of them have been along the lines of "over priced and over hyped"... not so with this bakery. This has been a favorite for many years and I think so many of the goods are just absolutely delicious. I used to regularly come here for their curry chicken pastry and fly it down to Irvine. The pastry could be frozen and then defrosted and baked later for a great meal. I absolutely LOVE the brown bread here as well. 

Recently I got the chocolate and blueberry scones. Both were tasty but I personally liked the blueberry one more. I also got the pork sausage rolls for breakfast which my bf and I loved. In addition, this time around I got the beef pastry and Shepard's pie to stick in the freezer. I am excited to try those on a lazy weeknight!
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
"Women are made to be loved, not understood" - Oscar Wilde, Irish Poet

John Campbell's Irish Bakery is "cut" from Dublin, Ireland "and pasted" to the outer Richmond District of San Francisco! It's where Irish legends are made and heck yea they have delicious morning pastries too! Ok, I honestly had no clue who John Campbell was, but I figured if he's Irish, he has to be pretty cool & kinda lucky... sure look it! 

So a few days ago I decide to grab a few Irish bites from John... it's still a chilly morning in early June here, so I stumble up Geary Blvd. until I reach his Irish Bakery - next door to the Blarney Stone Bar! A charming set-up, sans the cobblestones! A little piece of Ireland here in the outer O'Richmond!

As I walk-in I am warmly greeted by a "maybe" Irish young lady with a thick American accent! Ahh well! So I order a Beef Pastie, a Blueberry Scone & a Chocolate Scone. While the polite young lady heats up my Pastie, I notice all the souvenir t-shirts and little trinkets. Framed photos of dogs & people adorn the walls and just a feel for Enya! Since no tables are found I decide to get my hot tea next door at the other Irish coffee shop... O'starbucks! 

Yup, so I looked John Campbell up and came up with this... *John Campbell, Journeyman Baker from Belfast with more than thirty years of experience, has come to the Richmond District. 

John holds the Order of The Master Baker from Belfast, Belfast City, and holds a Guilds Bakery Certificate making him the repository of many decades of baking tradition in the authentic old style. With this wealth of experience, John Campbell's Irish Bakery opened on Geary on May 21st, 2007. The Irish Bakery offers traditional Potato Bread, Irish Crusty Bread, Brown Bread, Sultan Scones, and of course Soda Bread, all made in the very same fashion with the very same ingredients that your parents, grandparents, and great-grandparents might have enjoyed.*

After a few bites I can clearly see why John Campbell's has been around for over a decade while retaining such high ratings. It's the quality & love put into what they have to offer. Everything is good & quite filling, but if I must choose I'd say the chocolate scones wins my award. Not overly sweet, just done right... with a cup o' tea or coffee. Oh my! 

All in all, I recommend John Campbell's Irish Bakery! You can expect quality bites at affordable prices to boot! Yup, you still got those darn English taxes, but heck it's still worth all your sixpence! And 

May you always have walls for the winds,

a roof for the rain, tea beside the fire,

laughter to cheer you, those you love near you,

and all your heart might desire. My love to Ireland!
author: Eric R.

description: Don't come that often but it's a friends fave. I've tried the cookies and baked items before. This time I tried their shepherds pie and it was....kind've amazing. Who knew. They had chicken curry and the traditional beef peas and carrots. I went with the latter and exceeded all expeditions. Tried the hot cross bun and rhubarb streusel...just to be different. Not sure I would get those again but the beef shepherds pie...yes please.
author: Linda H.

description:
I'm going to go out on a wee limb and say that John Campbell's must be owned by the same lad or lassie who owns the Irish pub next door. This could certainly explain why John Campbell's doesn't go the way of the dinosaur. Having worked for a over a decade in bars, I know that the the mark up on booze is huge & one can make a mint in that business. Certainly, selling scones with inedible bits in them & serving half frozen pasties (see pictures) can't.

The decor at John Campbell's is perma-St Paddy's replete with shamrock bunting and 'gold' coins pilfered from a pot o' gold scattered about the otherwise mostly unadorned shelving. The vibe is meant to be festive, but the underwhelmed counter staff usually counteract any and all joy. 

Glad to read that some folk have had success with the brown bread & scones here. Visit JCs at your own risk, I'd say.
author: Bea B.

description:
I will never turn down a good scone, which means that I usually stop by to grab a scone or two... or six (c'mon, 6 for $8 is an amazing deal!) whenever I'm in the neighborhood. If you're used to the crumbly scones at Arizmendi, bear in mind that these scones will be probably be an acquired taste since they're a bit more bland in comparison, which is probably more in line with scones in Ireland. Think fluffy American biscuit, not American scone.

Still not convinced? Well, at $1.75, it won't break the bank if you decide to only buy one scone. My favorites are the blueberry and chocolate chip scones. The flavors are subtle and complement a good cup of tea. What's more, the scones still manage to taste fresh two days after purchase without having to slather loads of jam on top, which is what I hear you're supposed to do across the pond anyway.

Bakery is the size of a leprechaun's shoebox, so don't expect to eat in.
author: Amy C.

description:
I was in the area and decided to try the place out thanks to the good Yelp reviews. I am really surprised at the lackluster/bad experience I had in comparison to the reviews. 

I tried the scones - both the plain and the one with whipped cream. The plain one was stale and SUPER bland. The one with the whipped cream was in the same refrigerator as other savory products (I'm assuming), because it tasted like a "freezer" and smelled like onions.... oh and did I mention it was a blueberry+cream SWEET scone?!

I got a loaf of the wheat Irish soda bread. It was tasty. To be honest though, the rest of the products were so bad, I don't think I will ever go back. So disappointing especially since I wanted to relive part of my Irish vacation!
author: Anna M.

description:
I applaud the effort as there are no options for ex-pats in SF but come on. You know better than this. If you are going to take Cornish pasties, cream scones and traditional British and Irish food why mess around with short cuts?

Stuffed mincemeat into pastie. Too much meat in the sausage roll (not sausage meat flavor) and no lamb option for the Sheppard's pie?? A microwave to warm up into soggy goo. No meat pies? Not even a pork pie in sight. Costumer next to me is begging for a veggie pastie. You could do cheese and onion. It's a thing in the uk not hard to copy a greggs recipe. 

At least the Soda bread tastes like Soda bead. 

Please be a beacon of good home cooking not a reminder of British stereotype cooking of the 80's and 90's. John I know you have good ideas I can see it in the store. And get those sales staff to know how to heat things properly than kill your pastry work in the microwave!
author: Alex C.

description:
Great breakfast sandwiches and their chocolate chip scone is to die for! Yes please!! 

Some might feel it's a bit dry but I'm used to pastries this way!
author: Milan G.

description: Many friends and colleagues have highly recommended this place to me, but I found it very unimpressive and their scones were lacking in flavor. Their sausage roll was greasy and did not have much special taste to it. I wish I liked this place more, but I wasn't impressed by them. It's not bad, but I probably would not return.
author: rado l.

description:
Irish scones are now my favorite scones.

For those of you who haven't read my review of Arizmendi (https://www.yelp.com/biz/arizmendi-bakery-san-francisco?ylist=bakery-bonanza-san-francisco-2), I was a scone hater until I consumed the scones at Arizmendi, Home Run, and now, John Campbell.

Their BLUEBERRY SCONE, $1.75 each or 6 for $8, was soft and fluffy like a biscuit. The blueberries were sweet, making the dough reminiscent of a blueberry bagel. They offer a wide variety of flavors ranging from raisin to original, but I have an inkling that blueberry is the best.

Their SHEPHERD'S PIE, $9 each, is a beef pie with peas, carrots, and onions mixed with a rich brown gravy and topped with a crust of mashed potato. They can heat it up for you in the bakery, otherwise you can pop it in the microwave for 4 minutes at home. The filling is hearty and the mashed potatoes plentiful and buttery. I think was my first time eating shepherd's pie, and I know that I need more of it in my life.

I was also eyeing their mini tarts, but I was incredibly content with their blueberry scone and shepherd's pie. May the baked goods of the Irish be with you!
author: Adele F.

description:
Came here on the Saturday after St. Patrick's Day at 10 AM and all they had left was blueberry & chocolate scones.
DAMN YO.

The scone was really freakin' good and if it's the standard for their other items... I'll need to make a return visit!!

Scones are usually semi-dry and dense -- these were lighty, airy, and fluffy on the inside!. And not that super buttery or oily. Would go well with tea!!
author: Emily C.

description:
INVALUABLE  TIP: Scones will run out! (esp the cream filled ones + other pastries) 

Sunday morning, 10am: 
I had high hopes for trying their infamous Cream filled scones, but they were already out!!! Different questions and thoughts loomed in my head: "How little did they make that it would run out so fast? Did they not make enough? Or did someone just buy a whole bunch? Or is this place that popular?" 

I read other reviews before coming here, but none of the reviews mentioned that I had to be here early before they run out of their creme filled scones?!?! Yelpers, c'mon!  So, my tip for you guys is that if you want to try their scones, get there early! They open at 7am. Don't risk it and wait till 10am. 

I also noticed that other yelpers had pictures where the bakery case was filled with other pasties, like meat pies and such. When we arrived, the bakery case was EMPTY! I mean there was only a tray for the sausage filled pastry and this thick roll pastry topped with Bacon, Cheddar, and lots of onions. Warning! This pastry was loaded with onions! Left me with onion breath even though I only had a few bites. 

So, anyways, after being disappointed about the cream filled scones selling out, which the girl working there was NOT AT ALL sympathetic of my situation, I still had to buy something since I made the trek over here. 

I gave in to buying their "overpriced" Irish Soda Bread, which was HUGE, but also I don't think needs to cost $7.75!!! I bought it anyways. It was good and very bready. It's not dry like most soda breads I've eaten before. 

Also, I bought some scones for the road. Raisin and Blueberry scones for $1.75 each. These scones are a lot more buttery and doughy then most scones. They are soft, not dry. The texture is more like a biscuit than a scone.
author: Mel H.

description:
Chocolate bread.

Yes.  I warm it in the oven, & it becomes a wait-I-have-to-pause-now-because-holy-cow-this-is-so-good moment.  Melted, gooey chocolate speckled in a loaf of fresh, warm bread?  Oh yeah.

Since this is an Irish bakery, of course there is soda bread.  And of course there are scones.  There are also savory curry pockets.  Those were a bit of a let down for me...the curry flavor was decent enough, but they were overall unimpressive.  

The chocolate bread is the star for me here.

They also carry some imported Irish products, like tea & clotted cream.  Love.  And I have to note the reasonable prices, especially when compared to other artisan bakery standards.

If you're craving bread or scones in the richmond, it's certainly worth a stop.

3 & 1/2 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Blueberry scones are my favorite, I've had the Shepard's pie and lots of other tasty treats. Great service and they have super cute sugar cookies for kids.
author: Margret H.

description:
extortionist prices!

$8 for a small round of brown bread, $7 for a pasty! you might say, "why'd you do it, why'd you pay $5 for day old brown bread and $4.50 for a sad little sausage roll?!"

sigh. i wanted to get my fiance a treat from home he wouldn't normally see in san fran.

as observed in other reviews the interior of the bakery is drab and the staff border on surly.

AVOID
author: Lorraine Y.

description:
I finally got to step into this bakery after a year and a half of it catching my eye. It's a cozy little bakery shop catered to the person on-the go, meaning there is no seating. You just grab a bag and a pair of thongs and go. The blueberry and chocolate chip scones were delicious. Not dry and crumbly but also isn't so dense.  I got their meat pie as well and though it is a hearty way to put food in your belly, it was a bit too greasy for me. 

When I am in town next, I'll be sure to try something different but until now, I'd say it's 3.5 -4 stars for me.  The scones are worth making a morning trip.
author: Joy A.

description:
TL;DR - Really good treats in the display case.... but 0/3 for the sweets in the window display.

I was waiting for dim sum and wanted a little snack before heading over. I saw that the reviews for this bakery were pretty good and stopped by. The bf got a savoury focaccia (cheese and ham?) and I ended up getting the double chocolate cookie and a blueberry scone and a chocolate chip scone. Both the scones were pretty meh. Maybe I just don't like scones or something, but I liked the ones I've had at other places because they had a bit more buttery flavor. As for the cookie.... at two bucks, you get a thin (THIN) dry, crumbly, bland (can cookies even be bland) cookie. 

The bf's focaccia was delicious though! It was warmed up and very pillowy soft.
author: Crystal Z.

description:
Meh, my blueberry scone was alright. It tasted more like a blueberry biscuit than a scone. 

Not sure if I will ever come back, maybe for their puff pastries but I can imagine their other flavor scones tasting pretty much the same.
author: Kelly L.

description: The blueberry scone with whipped cream is superb! The sweetness of the cream is just right and the texture of the scone is so soft and fluffy. Just like the ones I had in England.
author: Melody H.

description:
Scones are huge but the taste was NOT good at all. Was I missing something? All I could taste was baking soda, or powder. I got one scone with the cream inside. The (imitation) cherry jam is too sweet. It wasn't fresh. Blah. I'd rather eat scones from Safeway. 

After reading reviews, I decided to finally stop in and try the scones. I walked in and there was no one else there other than the women behind the register. No "hello" or anything. Ok, whatever let me take a look at the scones. Behind me was an array of different scones on plates, cookies, and other pastries. I decide to bag me up some blueberry scones, and chocolate chip. Huge scones. Wow, can't wait to eat these.

Walk up to buy and I finally say "Hi..." She just looks at me like "yes." Told her it was my first time in and I also bought a Shepard pie($9). She told me the pies were refrigerated and to heat up in oven.

The Shepard pie was good after heating up in microwave because ain't nobody got time to preheat then heat up in oven.haha! Will only buy fresh out of the oven Shepard pie next time. Sorry, I will not be going back to this bakery.
author: Ane T.

description:
Since I live in the neighborhood, I wanted to swing by before work to pick up one of those scones filled with cream that everyone was raving about. When I paid and took a bite, I was quite disappointed. I think there were a few factors: 1) the scone was pretty cold -- don't think it was fresh and most likely from the day before 2) the cream was all-too buttery and left me with an icky feeling inside my mouth. I really didn't like the cream in the middle at all... 

I will probably come try their shortbread cookies to give this place another shot if it is 4.5 stars on Yelp. However, I will say that their pasties didn't look all that appealing to me and they're around $6-7.
author: Cindy W.

description: My first experience begins and ends with finding a strand of short, black hair cooked into the middle of my chocolate scone (refer to my photo). My hair is brown and long, so it sure isn't mine. So unsanitary and gross - I'm glad I didn't buy anything else. You really can't come back from that.
author: Mei H.

description: Decent spot for a variety of Irish items - not just baked goods, but also savory ones like pies and pasties. I didn't necessarily feel that the prices and quality were up to snuff, but it's still clear that this place has a good following, and it's always good to know that solid, dependable neighborhood establishments like this still exist in the West Bay. Cheers!
author: Vincent L.

description: Made a point to stop here on our trip to SF. Just like most places in SF parking will be a nightmare.  Bought the Irish brown bread and some blueberry scones. The brown bread is a little sweet... Tastes like it may have corn in it not sure.  The scone was only slightly sweet which was a plus for me. It's a small bakery. Seems pretty popular with the locals.  Good to try something different.
author: Rou M.

description: the worset service ever given by lazy woman always sitting on the chair not even greating customer???not fresh  food from a fridge as well poor food selection !only scones are great here and make s one star.....!too bad that the owners obviosly dont have idea wats going on and how good this bakery this used to be ......
author: Ivana P.

description:
Great spot for baked goods! They used to be cash only but I think they might accept cards now....but bring cash just in case.

Apple Puff - My favorite thing they make! Warm and amazing inside. 
Rhubarb Tart - Practically perfect in every way.
All the pasties are good. Make sure you get them hot. 
Sausage Roll - Tastes incredible, but know that you will get covered in grease. 
Scones are a little on the dry side (but that's what they are supposed to be), I like getting the ones with cream. 
This year I splurged and got one of the small plum puddings. I've never had one before so I can't compare it, but I wasn't really a fan. The flavor was good, but there were raisins in it. I can't stand raisins in baked goods. If I had known I wouldn't have bought it. My bad for not knowing what the heck plum pudding is.
author: Kari E.

description:
Pro tip: They also sell their goods at the Chinese-run Sweet Passion bakery on 40th and Taraval!

The biggest complaints I see here are 1) no parking and 2) running out of goods early in the day. Go to the Taraval location--problems solved!
author: Brittany L.

description:
Bitterly disappointed!  Did this place change hands or just have a cook now who has never baked?  
This was my all time favorite place to go for pies, pasties and sausage rolls.
I went there this weekend (Saturday to be precise) and bought meat pasties and sausage rolls.
Wow - completely inedible!   The pasty was filled with a brown mush, you couldn't even tell there was meat in it!
The sausage roll again was filled with a bland blended mix, that didn't even resemble any sausage meat I have ever eaten.
Very sad! :(
author: Jeannie S.

description:
After a very disappointing visit to Heartbaker around the corner, I insisted on visiting this place on our walk home. We passed by the window and entered the small store front with it's small selection. I believe we made it shortly before they were closing, but we were lucky enough to get one of their blueberry cream filled scones, and a vegetarian curry pasty. 

Let's just say that for whatever the place was lacking in style and selection, their scone was flavorful, soft, and perfect for a lightly sweet treat. My friend ate her pasty two days later and was still very impressed. It was spicy, filled with an Indian style curry, potatoes, and some other veggies. 

I definitely recommend this place and would come back in a heartbeat when I am back in the city. 
If we come back and they are just as good, or even better, I will definitely add another star.
author: Anna S.

description:
There are quickly perishable products behind the cold case: sausage rolls ($4), scones with cream ($3), pasties and a snack called, 'breakfast in bed' (bread with sausage, black + white pudding, eggs, and cheese baked into it).

The front window display is self-serve, grab a pair of tongs and a paper bag and help yourself to delicate tea cookies with lemon curd and raspberry jam centers (thumbprints) for $0.30 each. Glazed coconut shortbread cookies, crumbly blueberry scones (under $2 each) piled high in wooden baskets just screaming for preserves or clotted cream and curd. [ http://bit.ly/1ntmS6u ]

The problem with everything being so affordable, is that you have quickly shoved a dozen buttery tea cookies into your bag and now it's $3.60, plus your two scones with and without cream and your sausage roll. John Campbell's knows the name of the game. And the name is, shove this delicious Irish sausage encased in a puff pastry sleeve into my mouth, followed by several tea cookies the size of a half dollar coin...and all before the 38 has even approached the stop.
author: Illyanna M.

description: I like this place a lot but the counter girl is always surly and concentrated more on her phone than the customer. I hope she's a relative, but if not, I think y'all can do a lot better...
author: A S.

description: Never before did not eat Irish scones and Irish did not drink coffee. An incredible feeling, very tasty and unusual. I advise you to try !!!
author: Roman G.

description: Amazing spot and a staple in the outer Richmond. This place makes me love living in SF. Always fresh and delicious!
author: Herschel S.

description: This review is solely based on their blueberry scones. This was hands down the best scone I've ever had! Perfect balance of blueberry flavor and crisp crust while still soft and moist inside. And with the price of $1.75, it's pretty unbeatable! Will definitely be back for more next time I'm in the area :)
author: Carolyn L.

description: Just excellent brown bread. It's got a lovely sweetness and great crumbly texture. It's excellent toasted. I haven't been to Ireland yet, but my pal whose dad is Irish says that the scones served with clotted cream and jam are legit. Great airy, buttery scones. I wish they served currant scones more often, but the chocolate chip scones are super good.
author: X-topher B.

description: Shortbread cookies are delicious!  Very buttery and crisp.  Can't wait to try the other baked goods!
author: E F.

description: I would stay away from the sweet stuff, because they are just too sweet for my palate but I'm sure they are just fine for everyone else.  They have 2 types of Shepherd's pie.  Sausage roll.  Soda bread and brown bread (I don't know what they are).  Just a neat little shop.
author: J W.

description:
To write the most honest review I could have, I should have probably written it yesterday. I visited John Campbells a few days ago and it was basically all I thought about until I returned this morning for another dense, rich cream filled scone, but also to try a sausage pastie. 

As with everywhere else in our precious city, the parking is a nightmare. No, you think I'm being metaphorical - I am not being metaphorical. I am pretty sure the parking in this neighborhood has been the cause of at least a half dozen stress dreams. 

But hey, lets not hold that against them, yeah?
author: Selah D.

description: Delicious! However, if you run in while hungry and just can't make up your mind- it can get a little pricey. Here's a tip- these treats are hearty and you will probably only need one scone- or Irish soda read to satiate your carb-filled cravings. If you feel the need to imbibe some tasty libations- the bar next door is usually open. You could basically go between those two establishments and have a happy Saturday!
author: Martie A.

description: Scones were excellent and service was outstanding only issue for us was no coffee and nowhere to enjoy our snack.... need some tables for that cafe feel... will return for a shepherds pie or scones next time!
author: Paul D.

description:
I hear they call their cookies biscuits, and they call their biscuits scones, but who cares when you butter it up and put it in your face?

best biscuits called scones around.
author: Andy B.

description:
We completely stumbled on this little scone and baked goods spot and we are very happy we did!

So this review is for two things as we were just trying it out for the first time.

Day old bag of 4 poppy seed almond scones. $3

You know a place must have some killer scones if you can score a bag of 4 scones that are already a day old, freeze them, and reheat them in a hot oven the next day and they are fantastic. Not passable.  Not just good. FAN TA STICK. Moist and fragrant and still not crumbly.

So, the fresh scones must be quite remarkable and we will return for those for sure.

Beef pasty $6

So they had small mini samples of their Shepard's Pie ($8 for a single serving tray). And based on that delicious sample, I decided to try their Beef Pasty. A quick crisping of this meal in a pocket will have you stuffed (see pic http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QKNBWk_rERT2i_tduk77qw?select=1C5TblaU3bFliPrqZcyzzQ#xLedBVp9azj3WQQtLrFZ0w) with flaky crispy crust and a very generous filling of ground beef, onions, peas, and a delicious stew-like sauce. 

Truly comfort food if there was one. Kinda like a Shepard's pie without the potatoes (and a bit more portable).

This cash-only place. The service (nice woman behind the counter) was very pleasant and I am definitely coming back to sample more.
author: Glenn H.

description: The best coffee in the neighborhood and at the same time inexpensive. Every Wednesday I come from LA and just start the morning in the coffee shop. Beautiful pastries but not much to my taste. In general, I recommend !!
author: Alen A.

description:
John Campbel's features irish eats, bakery style. free samples of some offerings. shephard's pie delish. 1 order (9?) seem like a lot so went for something smaller
some of the "baked" goods looked more like meals or minis, not just snacks.

eats: sausage roll(4)
-flaky crust, meat loaf like meat
-tasty, no aftertaste
-nice  fulfilling snack

crumbs:
-friendly service, roll got heated up too.
-in & out in minutes.
-definite return if i see a parking space.
4.5 stars
author: Victor G.

description:
Picked up some Irish Soda bread for an office St. Patricks party and was very pleased. Super traditional and made the way it should be. 

Now my "go-to" for tasty, traditional Irish treats.
author: Emily E.

description: Cute takeaway bakery. The cream scone was good; though the scone itself was a little dry, the cream and jam filling made up for it. Try the pasties, remembering to call them PAHSTees not PAYStees, or else British friends might start laughing like mine did. They now accept credit cards.
author: doc m.

description: Passing by this place a lot when I used to take the 38 bus. Decided to try it honestly because my fav boyband was Irish haha. I yelped it and decided to get various different flavors of scones and also the corned beef. The blueberry scones are amazing!! It's so soft even though they were 2-3 days old.
author: Candice L.

description:
If you love doughy, sweet OR savory deliciousness, you're in the right place. I first came for the pasty's and occasional soup. I'm not a scone fan but the shortbread cookies and garlic focaccia are bar none. Nothing like taking a bite into a perfectly soft, buttery, herby, garlic clove with soft chewy dough.

Don't get me started on the almond raspberry tart. So yummy.
author: Shari W.

description: I have no other Irish bakery to compare this to, but damn this place is good. They have awesome blueberry and chocolate chip scones which they will gladly warm up for you. I am not even a scone person and instantly liked them. However, what really stood out was the beef pastie. It was awesome and really big. Like an oversized empanada, but better. It is a whole meal in itself and got me full (no easy task).  This is only a couple of blocks away from me and I cant believe it's taken me more then a year to finally make it here. Will definitely be back to try the other savory items like their shepherds pie, and a couple of other things.
author: Thielson D.

description: You just can't imagine how good it is until you bite into one of the scones and find heaven.  Want something savory - pasties!  Even vegetarian ones. This is a winner!
author: Virginia T.

description:
Being in the area several weeks ago, and ever the fan of a good scone (or two, or three), I couldn't help but drop by to give John Campbell's a try. While some of the other offerings there seemed promising (like the shepherd's pie and the pasties), I opted to just get myself a blueberry and a chocolate chip scone this time around.

Heating them up the next two days, one in the microwave (which was a mistake), and one in the toaster oven, I'd say that, simply, they were okay. Neither the worst nor the best I've had, with an alright texture once toasted and buttered, but a bit too bland and crumbly when dry. I definitely much prefer the scones I've had at some coffee shops in Taiwan, as well as the ones at Arizmendi, though they make a different variety than John Campbell's does (which I'd say is the more traditional version).

That said, not too bad, and I can see myself dropping by if I were in the area again, if not just to try some of the other offerings on hand.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A small little shop with DIY bread pickup, and display cases for the other pastries. I suspect some of the bread higher up or lower down may prove a little more difficult to grab, but, otherwise, the bakery is accessible.

Bathroom - Pretty sure there isn't one for customer use.
author: Johnny W.

description:
The one Irish bakery I know of in San Francisco, and the only one I need! John Campbell's forgoes the all-too-common Irish kitschy bric a brac, focusing instead on what you came for: the scones, pasties, sausage rolls, shepherd's pies, and other baked goods. The decorations are pictures/drawings of a couple dogs, which I assume are the owner's. You have an Irish blessing and a letter to the Republic signed by James Connolly (maybe the Easter Proclamation? the text was small). Rather more authentic than throwing Joyce/Wilde etc. everywhere. 

Moving on to the food: there's no seating here, so you'll be getting everything to eat to go. I've had the plain scone, blueberry scone, plain scone with cream and jam, meat pasty (very much like a Cornish pasty), and chicken curry pasty. The scones are great, denser and a bit drier than my mother's, but good nonetheless. At home we'd do scones with jam, but with cream and powdered sugar works very well with these because they're denser. The meat pasty is fantastic, very filling giving the price. I wasn't actually a fan of the chicken curry pasty, the curry was very dry and the consistency was weird. The one thing here I haven't liked!

While here, grab some Barry's, the finest tea. And maybe a Lucozade too, though I end up getting one more for the sentimental value than because I like them.
author: Eoin N.

description: We got a slice of the corned beef slice. At $5 a slice it packs a lot- beef, potato, garlic, cabbage, cheese, ranch, Dijon mustard, butter, and cream. It was super filling! The Dijon was a bit too overpowering and masked the other flavors. We asked to have our slice heated up but after a 3-5 min wait the slice was still lukewarm. We asked for it to be heated again and again, the slice came out to be just about the same temperature as it was before.we should have just taken the slice home and stuck it in our oven. I think it would have tasted much better.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Oh mom, how you embarrass me.

If you see a woman wearing a thick jacket with a bob cut eating all the samples, that would be my mother.

She just can't help herself here.

Irish soda bread. Blueberry scones, whatever you want to give her, she'll take it, thank you, and ask for more.

So, every time we come here, I feel inclined to buy dozens of scones for the guys at the office so they can enjoy it with our new espresso machine, and so that I don't feel guilty.

Thanks for feeding her your lovely samples.
author: Jack R.

description:
I liked this bakery but honestly I was expecting a lot more. 

For one: There is no seating. Don't be like me and come all the way out here expecting that you'll be able to sit down and enjoy a piping hot pastie with coffee (which is what I was hoping for). Instead, I had to slither into a local coffee shop, buy coffee, and feel a bit guilty about openly eating someone else's baked goods instead of ordering the baked goods at the coffee shop. I tried to clean up the crumbs as best I could.

Scones with cream: Decadent and good. There was also strawberry sauce (like the ice cream sauce) in it and it definitely tasted nice.

Chicken curry pastie: A lot of chunks of potato and a bit light on the chicken. Flavor was there but the crust was kind of flat and not flakey enough to be outstanding. Also it was a bit cold by the time I decided to go to the local coffee shop.

Soda bread: Good. Nothing to write home about but a good, semi-dense bread with raisins interspersed and a thick crust. 

Blueberry scone: Liked it. It's not too dry but I like my scones on the buttery melty side. It was a bit more... bread-like. Also I like them with tea... but ate it before I got to the coffee shop.
author: Sylvia L.

description: The best mince pies this side of the Pond! We always come for the yummy pasties (beef is my favorite) and the scones. We stopped by and thought I'd try the mince tart. We had a mince pie from Nations (the only place we could find one this year in Fremont). It was good but when I tasted the mince tart it was night and day! Next year I will make the trip to ST just for that pie! Yes, it was that good :-),
author: L. B.

description:
Love the scones!  I always stop at this little place on my way back to Los Angeles.  It's just so good! 

Cash only!
author: Kristin H.

description:
Whoa Man. 

How is this so close and I had no clue? Cookin up hearty things from pies to pastries, JCIB is holding it down for the Irish.

We stopped by on a walk out to Ocean Beach and got some scones, which were dense and exactly what we needed after a night of drinking. While there we sampled the various pot pies which made me wish it was a rainy day and I was at home in my sweats, chowing a pie down in front of the fire. 

Weather aside, this small bakery has some great offerings that you just can't find in a grocery store or coffee shop. Check it out!
author: Katie K.

description:
Note that not all items on the website menu are available consistently. They advertise an almond raspberry tart but it is, according to the person behind the counter, available only on a random basis. I recommend calling ahead.

I tried a chocolate chip scone, which was passable; the sausage roll and chicken focaccia were also perfectly serviceable.
author: James W.

description:
great little place with a nice selection of baked goods, pasties, shepherds pie, etc.  Everything I have tried from there is very good.  The other night I ordered the chicken veg pastie and asked her to heat it up.  She asked if I was going to eat it at the Blarney Stone, and when I answered in the affirmative she told me that she would bring it over when it was ready.

So on top of the good food, good service too.
author: Jeff H.

description: Soggy biscuits and moldy cheese... Is what I ate today at John Campbell's. Hmm, ya wasn't really feeling that stale Bellfast Bap. Refund? Or maybe just another soggy cheese biscuit please
author: Elijah C.

description: This is a no frills kind of bakery. We got a beef shepard's pie and a blueberry scone. I'd recommend the shepard's pie for sure. They also heat it up for you too.
author: Anne L.

description: 100% Irish and fancied a taste of home.  Had been here in the past,but my most recent visit changed my mind about this place.  Got a pork sausage roll and asked for it to be heated, it was heated way too long and done in microwave so taste like rubber and the meat filling was not real meat but maybe a substitute so totally not enjoyable.  Grease coming off sausage roll was beyond normal so threw most of it in trash. Plain scones were okay also ,but could be better.
author: Alan H.

description:
I'll admit...thus far I've only come in for the scone. But...the scone is buttery, sweet and delicious. =)

The staff here was very friendly, and very nice. There wasn't a huge like or a large group of people in my way, which is always nice. Then again...with so many positive reviews, I fear a line. Please, hipsters and yuppies stay away!
author: Lily W.

description:
This review is for the 2nd store on Fillmore street (Yelp moved it without explanation).

Sunday, March 21st is National French Bread Day, so I decided to review this new bakery that opened last week. The store is located on a corner opposite to Real Food Company, in the Marina-Cow Hollow area. This is the 2nd location for this popular Irish bakery of the Richmond district. Love the soda bread, scones, shortbread cookies, pastries (and "pasties", the food kind), etc. http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XMlcY1yf91VLmMaY5EzKfQ/l

In case you didn't know this bakery supplies the baked goods for Lovejoy's Tea Room, and the breads for the sandwiches from Roxie's Market & Deli. I was told that the location is operated by the owner's daughter.

Hours:
Mon-Sat 7am-10pm
Sun 7am-8pm
author: Luis C.

description: This small Irish Bakery caught my eye with it's window display of breads, scones, and danish looking pastries. I purchased a plain scone and a chocolate chip scone. I don't know how Irish scones should taste but I prefer mine a tiny bit sweet. These were plain but when warmed up with some butter were tasty. I also bought a $6 circular loaf of sun dried tomato and pesto bread. I took it home and ate it with some cheese. It was so good it was gone between two people at the end of the day! The man behind the counter was friendly and helpful even while busy with customers in front of us. They have tasty looking sandwiches and lemon tarts at the counter... I had to leave before I piled one of everything into my bag! If you're in the neighborhood, stop by and indulge in some cheap baked goodies.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Him: Whatcha eating? Pot pie..? 
Me: Chicken curry pasty from this Irish bakery I found in the City.
Him: Oh! Off Geary and twentysomething.
Me; Yeah! Between 20th and 21st.
Him: Right. John...?
Me: Campbell's!
Him:  That's it!

True story. 

Our most recent, and first trip, here was like being a kid in the candy store.  In the storefront, you're greeted with all of these wonderful smelling baked goods such as cookies, soda bread, and scones.  Oh, the scones.  Hard to pick just one, and luckily they have a deal for 6.  The baked treats are a good start.. but then, you turn around and are slapped in the face with too much good stuff.  Shepherd's pie, a variety of pasties (chicken & veggie, chicken curry, and beef), cream-filled scones??  I mean, c'mon.. showing self-restraint here is asking a little too much.  Also on sale on their shelves include international favorites such as HP sauce, Bird's Custard Powder, clotted cream, and Flake. Nice addition and saves a trip to Cost Plus World Market.  

Curious as to our latest bill?  Deep breath.. here goes... 

- 2 chocolate-covered shortbread triangles
- 4 shortbread cookies, 
- 6 scones (3 chocolate chip, 3 blueberry)
- 2 chicken curry pasties
- 2 beef pasties -- great as a snack if shared or as a meal for one
- 1 cream-filled blueberry scone

All for a price tag of $40.  I regret nothing.  All items fall under the umbrella of utter deliciousness.
author: Shereen R.

description:
I can not leave the Bay Area without visiting this bakery.
The savory items all remind me of the home cooked treats I got as a kid in England, and the sweet temptations are addictive. We leave with every intention of delivering samples of the fare to our friends, but a 4 hour trip to Reno leaves the paper bags empty. Sorry friends!
I recommend trying..........
What the Heck, everything. If it's not good you won't find it on display.
Grab a jar of picked onions from the shelf to enjoy with a sausage roll or pastie.
author: Sim B.

description:
So I should have written a review for this place a long time ago as we visited it last November.  
I was so excited to go here seeing as I'm from England.  I was longing for good scones as for some reason the American scones are always so dry.  Also reading all the reviews and looking at the pictures was making my mouth water.

I kind of knew what to expect from reviews and pictures on Yelp, but actually stepping into this bakery and seeing all the goodies was another thing.  I was like a kid in a candy shop.  So many choices and wonderful flavors to choose from that I couldn't decide what to get.  I wanted one of everything.  Luckily there were a few samples on the counter which helped make my decision easier (but not much).  They had samples of their mince pies which are to die for and an Irish bread called Soda bread which was different (but good) that I'd never tried before.  I really miss really good mice pies.  

OK so this is what I ended up getting:-
-4 Mince pies
-One plum pudding which I saved for Christmas so my family could try.  It's like a cross between Christmas pudding and fruit cake.  Moist, flavorful, and oh so good.  Next time I go I'll buy several of these as they do keep forever.  
-3 different pasties which me, my son, and husband ate for lunch.  Absolutely delicious
-A couple of scones.  I was in heaven eating them.  I didn't have any clotted cream so I ended up eating them with butter and jam. 
-One loaf of their soda bread
-Several shortbread cookies for my son

I definitely want to go back and try their other baked goods and also their shepherd pie looked so delicious.  Just a shame that it's in SF and I live in the South Bay.
author: Rosetta C.

description: Intrigued by the thought of an Irish bakery (not something you see everyday), I stopped in to see what they were offering.  The savory pies and pasties looked the best, but I had just eaten a sizable meal, and decided to grab a few sweet scones. The reviews on Yelp rave about their scones, and I guess that is one of their specialties.  Maybe it is just me, but both the chocolate chip and the blueberry scones seemed dry and bland.  Coffee helped to improve the situation, but not by much.  If I ever find myself that far out on Geary again, I may stop in for a meat pie of some kind, but I wouldn't go out of my way to return.
author: Mark A.

description:
I had a craving for soda bread (don't judge me, I'm pregnant) and went into John Campbell's because, well, I don't know of any other place that has soda bread.

I was disappointed to find they didn't have any of the mini soda breads that I got last time. However, the kind gentleman behind the counter gave me plenty of options. They still had the raisin soda bread but since I think raisins are the cause of all the evil in the world, we moved onto the next option.

Brown bread. There was a piece left to sample. I took one bite and was sold. Boy, was I not disappointed! I might have a new go-to! The bread was delicious... moist, chewy, dense... like good soda bread should be.

On top of that, the guy behind the counter saw the disappointment on my husband's face when I denied the raisin invasion, so he offered to give us a BOGO free deal. Well shoot, why the hell not? We added a double chocolate almond tart to our order and walked out with awesomeness in a bag.

Double chocolate almond tart. The name says it all.

An overall great experience. If you don't know what soda bread is, this is the place to start!
author: Sara K.

description:
Not the crumbly kind of scones, but the ones that melt in your mouth. I go here in the mornings & the scones always taste so fresh.

Minus one star for the cashier giving me the wrong change.
author: Catheria S.

description: Updating as I like these guys , but want to get a serious point to the owners. I was there to buy a ton of stuff for my office at 8am and got only left overs. To the owners- you're a breakfast place and if you want people to go there, delivering at 11 am isn't acceptable. If you must have day old stuff you should charge half price. I'm the guy who wants to spread the good word about you but if the stuff isn't fresh I can' do that. Please use my experience as a lesson.
author: J F.

description:
sweet, not too buttery and satisfying. 

apple custard cake - yummy! can't have too much at once because it does get a bit cloying. 

blueberry scone - tastes like other scones i've had but less crumbly and butter (which is a plus for me).
author: Jenny L.

description:
I wasn't aware San Francisco had an Irish bakery until I was wondering around Geary Blvd. looking for boba.  This Bakery had a Stout Coffee, as strong as an Irish beer, and good bread.  Everything looked, smelled, and tasted amazing.  Bread is nothing to take lightly because carbs should be a staple in everyone's diet, even if you are on a diet.

Anyway, will be back.  The lady that works here, didn't catch her name, was super nice and friendly, too.
author: Hazel K.

description:
This place has been around for a long time and I've walked by quite a bit just to stare into the window to look at their good looking pastries. Finally my intrigue for fresh baked goods got the best of me as I was lured into this bakery hoping to grab some carbs. The store is cute and decked out with sweet and savory treats of all kinds. There was a gamut of scones, open face sandwiches, tarts, and other delicious looking breads but I was already wedded to the fruity and chocolaty options that were sitting pretty by the window. 

I thought my apple puff had a nice smooth flaky texture on the outer-layer, but the powdery sugar was not enough to inspire a lackluster taste in the chopped apple spread. My fruit bun was much more dense and hearty than expected with a nice sprinkles of cherries, walnuts and raisins, and the texture resembles much more like a scone than a sweet bread. 

My chocolate snowball was sinfully coated with a layer of coconut on top of thick dark chocolate with cake-like filling embedded with raspberry jam. It was one of the items where the taste was robust and distinguishable. My huge foccacia bread tasted similar to the ones at Giovanni's Cafe, and the thick doughy texture was pretty good to go with a thin spread of olive oil and chopped herbs and spices. 

Overall I thought the food was decent with a few uninspiring spots. My order costs $6.50 which I thought could be lesser since the use of ingredients were pretty straight forward. This is a good place for those interested in baked goods that emphasize on heartiness than sweets. Service was very friendly and welcoming. 3 stars for the overall experience.
author: Daniel L.

description: I am never in this neighborhood so I was happy to finally try something from here. I always passed by on a bus or car. I git the blueberry scone it was good tasted and looked more like a biscuit. The pies looked good and some cream stuffed pastry, I need to make a trip there again.
author: Karen T.

description: Such a cute little place! My boyfriend and I tried 4 different items, unfortunately I felt as though  the food was lacking in flavor. That same day it was raining, we had gone there for breakfast.. they had no where to sit inside or outside. That being said my boyfriend and I had to eat on the curb, that put a real damper on the whole experience!
author: Caitlin A.

description:
Pretty small little bakery, and certainly of the old-school variety. It's in a very unusual location, nestled among a bunch of Chinese restaurants every couple steps on Geary. No place to sit or anything, purely a buy and take-to-go shop.

I got blueberry scones and they were serviceable but not spectacular. The ratio of buttery/creaminess to flour seems to be favoring extra dough, so it wasn't as crumbly as I was hoping. The blueberries are SUPER though, they burst in your mouth like little sour-sweet gems.

It seems like the cream scones (which are in the display case near the register) would have been the more satisfying choice, but it also would've been much more messy to carry away. I really liked the chicken pot pie sample they gave, but ultimately was ho-hummed by the establishment in general.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
14.04.17.            5th visit
                           Short review ... will add more next visit

Food ---------------- 4

Recommend
        Beef pastie .... reheat on both side with a pan ... killer
        garlic his version bread
        Basically kept ordering the pasties (meat) several times (that's why short list)

Will try the others later

Have imported Irish products and a tasty orange soda.
author: S.K. Y.

description:
Irish Spring.

It is raining Irish this year and I never asked for it.  It just happened.  

2009 has been odd from the start.  Dating?  Men from Dublin, men from Waterford, Limerick.  The lovely Irish accents (Gaelic from one made me swoon).  Hung out with the Irish in Boston and then vice versa here in SF.  I'm loving this experience, made even better with the damn soda bread served at Foley's.  I was munching on that even though I ordered my usual hamburger.  

I've passed by this bakery many a time but just never went in.  Granted the lovely baked scones and breads have always been puffing themselves up at me but I've never paid any attention.  Fast forward to recently and I did go in after perusing the counters at the Kosher deli next door.  Large fresh scones with chocolate, blueberry, and raisins topping the wicker baskets in the display window.  Shortbread cookies with heavy glazing.  Breads.  Soda bread.

This is help yourself service, so grab one of the little white baggies and proceed ahead with picking what best entices you.  In my case, I selected three of the almond shortbread cookies with the white sugar glaze, one blueberry scone and one Irish Liquer Almond Scone.  

One of the things that seem to deter me from purchasing some scones is that there is a slight bitter aftertaste down my throat.  Why?  Too much baking powder can shift that subtle balance in the batter and unfortunately, such was my experience with the Irish Liquer Almond Scone.  A slight disappointment.  However, I did nibble away at the blueberry scone, delightful, crumbly and chock full with berries.  The cookies were somewhat disappointing because the lovely buttery shortbread was hidden beneath the thick glaze of sugar icing.  I did not even have the heart to offer any to the fellow, since it was basically munching on a sugar glaze wafer.  Ah, the deceit!

Otherwise, a cute little escape off the Geary and if you desire scones, this is the place.  I'm upping the rating to another star because one bad scone does not mean the entire batch is bad, although that would rebut the theory that one bad apple ruins the entire bushel.  I'll be going back to try their other baked items.  Perhaps the loaf of soda bread.  

And that with a pat of Kerrygold butter is a guaranteed good thing.
author: Miika M.

description:
I really haven't tried anything but the scones, but the scones are wonderful.   The best place I know of in SF for this sort of thing.  A great value too at 6 scones for $6!   Without fail, when I have house guests, they spy this place down the block and then stake out the bakery each morning demanding more scoooonnnnnnnes.

It's best early in the morning when the scones are fresh from the oven and the selection is full.   If you arrive later in the morning, do ask the staff if there are fresher scones - they usually have more in the back and are happy to give you fresher ones if you ask.
author: Heidi M.

description: The pork sausage and hot coffee is the perfect way to start a day
author: Joe L.

description: Customer service on point. Just didn't like my blueberry scone with cream. . Cream tasted a little old. My apple tart was eggy tasting. It was flakey which was nice... their brown bread was delicious.   Disappointed with my first time trying this place.
author: Gigi C.

description: Yum! We were passing by and saw the breads and scones in the window - scrumptious. We got the Irish crusty bread - heavenly taste and texture, though ours was slightly underbaked.  Regretfully, we didn't try the scones. If we are ever in the area again, we will give them a try. I wished more places offered bread like this.
author: Kaya B.

description:
Favorite bakery. Everything here is delicious.
Potato Farls are my favorite!!!!
author: Diana R.

description:
Don't be fooled by the dingy storefront, John Campbell's has some superstar pastries that will make you forget its outer Richmond distant location! Apparently many cafes and afternoon tea spots order their pastries from here, which definitely says something.

The bad: a tiny, rather unremarkable storefront on Geary

The good: the baguette was decent, and they really do have some seemingly authentic Irish pastries like the sausage bun/pastry (really really good and savory), not to mention their focaccia and other finds.

Overall: a small neighborhood bakery, good for a quick savory breakfast or afternoon snack.
author: Jackie T.

description:
As we were driving along Geary Blvd I noticed this Irish Bakery and was immediately intrigued by it. I pointed it out to hubby and on our way back we stopped by to take a look. Naturally as we entered I noticed several items I wanted to buy, although, I wasn't sure when I'd be able to eat them all. I picked up some raisin scones, the Guinness bread, mince tarts, chicken curry pastie. As I went to pay, the nice guy behind the counter asked me if I'd ever tried their blueberry scone. I said no I had not. I said they didn't have any out there. He said well that's true, but there is one left -- one which he was planning to take home with him, but I could have that one. WOW.... now that's what I call customer service.

We chatted a bit and when he found out that was our first trip there he said he would throw in some brown bread for us to try as well. He cut half of a loaf and gave that to us. I was even more surprised to find that he wasn't the owner, nor was he even part of the family. This guy just works for them and you know what? Mr John Campbell, or whoever the owner is should be so lucky to find an employee like this, who is so passionate about the wares he sells and has such a personality to deliver this love to the customers.

As we were leaving, the young man got a hold of some garlic bread sample and ya guessed it..... we had to buy the loaf of garlic bread as well.

Once again I am saddened by the fact that I no longer live in the Bay Area and I am no longer surrounded by anything that vaguely resembles what can be called culinary diversity.

By the way -- that blueberry scone was to die for. The curry pastie was so delicious even the next day although the pastry portion wasn't flaky anymore, but the filling was just awesome. And the Guinness bread? He said that it would be good for a week and he was right. After 5 days it's still tasty as ever although I doubt it'll last past tonight once hubby gets his hands on it. The brown bread -- slightly salty taste which, with a dollop of your favorite preserves makes it just outta this world!!
author: Anita L.

description: Firstly- LOVE that they have samples for you! Since the food is not what one is typically used to in this area (how often do you find Irish bakeries around?), it's great that I can taste a decent portion of Shepherd's pie before purchasing. I have gotten their Shepherd's pie & Veggie Curry pasty before ($7-9), both bursting with flavor. I've also gotten their specialty breads, like their focaccia, which are not as good but still do the trick for $2. Definitely come here for comfort food on a cold day, to grab something warm and filling that you'd probably be too lazy to make yourself.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Wanted a treat after a long line in the post office, and oh boy am I glad my grumpy self came in here!

I got a coffee, blueberry scone, garlic cheese bread, and an apple puff for about $8.  I'm not particular on my coffee so I can't quite judge that (it was strong though) but the 3 baked goods I got were far beyond delicious.  

The other Yelpers weren't lying, the scone was decadent.  Garlic cheese bread - cooked all the way through, lots of cheese, and perfectly roasted garlic cloves, almost sweet not a strong garlic like you'd expect.  Apple puff - yummy puff pastry with apple pie-like filling topped with powdered sugar, would choose one over a donut any day!

The girl at the counter was also extremely helpful.  I was being a slowpoke, and she sat there and waited while I went back and forth between the window treats and the ones in the case.  After all that waiting and other customers, she even offered me a fresh coffee even though the one in my hand was perfectly acceptable.  I can't wait to go back, the Yelp pics are making me drool all over again.
author: Megan A.

description:
Get the Irish Liquer Almond Scone. It is crumbly, but still dense and lures you with a subtle sweet smell which reminds me of Disaronno Liquer.

I read the yelp reviews after I got home. I'm gonna have to come back to try the meat pies!
author: Janice C.

description: I absolutely LOVE this bakery.  Why didn't I discover this gem sooner?  Their pastries are definitely unique and everything here is delicious.  I'm not a very big fan of scones, but they've made me a believer.  Their scones are so yummy!  I've tried the chocolate chip both with filling and without as well as the blueberry.  Their scones are more on the moist side and go great with coffee or tea.  Their sausage rolls and their shepard's pies are both very filling and flavorful.  I believe they're open until 7pm on most days but they do sell out on their popular items so be sure to stop by early and grab a few.  Ever since my coworker told me about this place, I've visited numerous times in the past couple of months.  That's how you know you've found a good spot.  When their goodies are good enough for you to return.
author: Christine D.

description:
Having walked by this Irish bakery many times and noticing all the scones, breads, and cookies in the window, we decided to walk-in for a closer look at all these delicious looking goodies.

They had several types of scones:  plain, almond poppyseed, blueberry, and chocolate; soda bread, cookies and an apple puff that was topped with powdered sugar, which we decided to buy.

When we paid at the counter, we noticed more varieties of bread, shepherd's pie and foccacia sandwiches.  As we left the bakery, with our Starbucks in hand, we started on the apple puff.  Wow, it was light and flaky with a good amount of apple filling.  It was so delicious that I could have had a couple more.  

This is strictly a take-out place.  No tables to sit down and enjoy the delicious baked goods.  

We'll be back to try the other goodies at this great bakery.
author: Al L.

description: Sausage rolls!! I love this bakery and the staff are always the best. It's great to have some delicious irish food here in the city. I recommend the sausage rolls with some brown sauce, they're just like home. The brown bread is definitely worth a try too.
author: Colly M.

description:
I'm a big fan of the scones, brown bread and veggie or curry chicken pasties at John Campbell's. The pasties are often enough for two entire meals. 

My only complaint is that the prices are a bit high.

Still, a trip to their bakery is a nice occasional indulgence. 

Fans of irish products such as taytos and lucozade will find a pre-packaged taste of home at a premium.
author: Carole B.

description:
I've popped in here twice in the past year and EVERYTHING I have tried so far, has been absolutely delicious!!

Try the apple turnovers or any of their delightful scones.  All of which are best shared with your partner in crime.

Yummy!!!
author: Anthony D.

description: Lived in uk for a long time and recently moved to sf, really craving for some pasty and a taste of Britain. Found this place in yelp and I decided to take a bus to go all the way to this bakery for some scone n pastry. I was disappointed, the pasty was horrible, only minced meat, peas n carrots inside and they just have the same ingredients for the shepherd pie. They are nothing taste like what I had in the uk...
author: Eskimo M.

description:
Unlike many "bakeries" where you are likely to find an array of junk foods, sugar, and perhaps a bagel, this place offers legit, satisfying baked goods (in addition to the sugary goods) such as:
- Shepherds Pie (delicious)
- Soda bread 
- "Flatbread" with bacon, cheese and tomato (amazing)
- a sausage sandwich thing that I'll be trying next time. 

Highly recommend this little place. Love it.
author: Frankie S.

description:
There is much to love about the Irish: Their luck, their charm, their whiskey, and now, John Campbell and his bakery. 

While there is an occasional staffer that is a little salty for my liking, that is not the case with the baked goods! I've been in the neighborhood about a year a half and have had the pleasure of tasting many of John's goods. I've enjoyed the scones, the cookies, the loaf breads, and everything else they have to offer and I'm pleased with the consistency in quality that John offers. Never, not ever, have I eaten something and thought, "Eh...it was just kind of 'off" today." Truly a sign of a great baker. Window displayed treats range from $.25 - about $2. Counter display items are more meal like and are 4 to 8 bucks, or so. And they have samples all the time!

Among my favorite savories: Chicken Curry Shepherd's Pie, Chicken (or Vegetable) Curry Pasty, Garlic Pecorino bread (YUM), Potato bread and most recently, the Roast Beef Fococcia sandwich. (Oh.Em.Gee. Sliced just thick enough, cheesy, and flavorful with a little kick. Unexpected hit the spot last night for a quick dinner.)

My favorite sweet treats are the Chocolate Almond Tarts and the Cream-filled Blueberry Scones dusted with some powdered sugar. I rarely indulge in these as Operation Bridesmaid Bod is currently underway, but seriously, if you're going to do it wrong, do it right!

Be prepared that it's cash only. Perhaps mildly inconvenient at times, but as they are a small business that provides high quality product at incredibly reasonable prices, I will am more than happy to visit the ATM to put pure Irish Happiness in my belly.
author: Suganthi J.

description:
So glad we drove by and somehow the sign caught my eye.  Hubby let me off the car to go check it out - I thought I would just grab the brown soda bread loaf and go but there are so many tasty looking treats in there that I cannot deicde...so I signaled for hubby to park. Luckily, there was a meter space and we put in our pocket of change for 10 minutes.

Don't be fooled thinking there's only soda bread, there are sconces, candies, some condiments, drinks and other treats like shepherd's pie...etc.

We ended up with the raisin soda bread - $5.50 and a Bailey's cream sconce at $2 or $1.50?  I know you get a better deal if you buy 6 and it's likely not difficult since they have other flavors too like plain, bluberry, chocolate and others.  You just grab a paper bag (in varoius sizes), a tong and pick the items you want.

We were thinking about the brown dense soda bread we really enjoyed from O'Reiley.  Turns out they have it but did not get today...but we shall return and get one.

Besides baked goods (breads, cookies, sconces...), they also carry some candies that remind me of childhood like Smarties, fruit pastilles, Maltesers chocolate among others and Lucozde energy drink!

Can't wait to return, what a cool place to pick up some tasty treats!
author: Gloria H.

description:
2 words: rhubarb pie.

2 more words: brown bread.
author: Helen Y.

description: Even though the pastries were good the lady behind the counter was having a bad day, she said "she was training  her coworker and had a long day' and boy did she! I felt sorry for her coworker to be with her all day yeah i know we all have bad days
author: Ric H.

description:
So I have not been to their original one on Geary.  But I happened to be on foot... and I saw Irish BAKERY.  (Yeah, I know, no alcohol!) lol

Apparently they've only been open since March 15, 2010...so I'm happy to review 'em. 

I tried a sample of their brown bread, and bought a loaf for $5.25.  Now mind you, it is a small loaf, but it is a very hearty whole wheat bread and it goes a loooong way. :)

And then I also bought a snowball (coconut cake-like thing spliced with raspberry jam filling.) Sooo much better than the Hostess ones. :)

Finally, I caved in and bought a Mince Puff.  It's a flaky pastry, with a delicious blend of chopped apples, raisins, spices and citrus.  Love it!

Curiosity got the better of me, so I asked about soda bread.  They usually have it but it was sold out.  (It was around 4:30 p.m.) Yeah, I'll be back...
author: Fannie S.

description:
- like a little travel vignette. . .  You don't need to be Irish to know that this stuff is Hibernia  ÜBER Hella Delicious.

Scones, crumpets, fruit filled hand pies, coconut puffs! . . .  I could easily buy one of each out of the 8 baskets in the pane window, THEN there's the goodies in the "warmer" display case next to the counter (would elevate it up to the level of "spendy"!).  .  .  jams, and tea & coffee. . .  Is there a table & chair to sit, sip Irish tea, and side-chat with the colleen behind the counter?

Ireland IS on Geary street!

Faith & Begora.

Enjoy
author: Clifford L.

description:
I passed by on the way to the Russian deli and couldn't help stopping in. Despite the somewhat hefty $6 price tag, I grabbed a loaf of the brown (whole wheat Irish soda) bread.

Wow. It was some of the best bread I've ever had. Flavorful, soft and chewy. Outright addictive. 

So good, in fact, that I drove 5 miles in a zipcar the week after to get two more loaves.

The cinnamon sugar baps were awesome too.
author: Jenny B.

description: I absolutely love this bakery! i will say it's worth the drive and hassle to find parking just for a scone or just  grab basically everything in the store.  I got the raisin and blueberry scones. Both were fresh and it went really well with the cream i got at cost plus.  It feels like i was eating a scone at Lovejoy's .  Which in my opinion has the best scones out of all the high tea places. The girl behind the counter was so helpful. I was mainly being one of those customers that asked about everything, like oh what's this? what is your favorite? etc...  I don't know the name of the item i got, but it was a round powdered doughnut looking pastry but it wasn't a doughnut. There were apples baked inside and it was so fluffy.  It wasn't too sweet and it was super soft.  I regret that i only got one, the next time i go back i'll prob get half a dozen just for myself. I didn't ask if they sold cream to go with the scone but if you want cream you can stop by Cost plus world market for it.  Overall, i love this place, i just wished they took over the stores next door and expanded, because it would be a great place to come here to relax and study.
author: Belinda C.

description: Soda bread was not worth the price. No caraway and really no taste. We had to slather it with butter and still it did not compare to many supermarket soda breads. Customer service was lacking. Rude girl, may have been manager, curt with customers and seemed to be in a bad mood. Try Copper Kettle on Taraval for delicious soda bread and friendly employees.
author: Penny K.

description:
I chanced upon this little bakery on my way to dinner at Kasa, and the mouthwatering selection of baked goods in the window brought me in.  Soda breads, tea cookies, scones, snowballs (?), and further inside, savory items, miniature tarts and other desserts.  

Loved the generous samples offered (also much needed, since I'm a bit new to Irish pastries) and really reasonable prices!   And my purchases were downright delicious- the chocolate scone especially.

I'd love to head back for a taste of their shepherds pie and maybe even grab a couple snowballs for dessert.

Ultra friendly people work here.  Cash only.
author: Joanne G.

description: Very good bread, cookies muffins, so far the best bakery on Geary that I've been too.
author: Rick V.

description: One of the driest scones i've ever encountered. That is my thought every time I pass this place on the 38L.
author: Rose M.

description:
After falling in love with the scones at Lovejoy's Tea Room and discovering that they are not made in-house but rather baked by John Campbell's, I had to satiate my craving and curiosity and check out this hole in the wall bakery. Upon arriving at 10:00 am on a Saturday, I raced in to find bare shelves and no scones. No scones?! What the phuck?! What kind of bakery is this, and where the heck is their kitchen? Disappointed, I asked the jaded young woman behind the counter, and she replied that they would be delivered at any minute. Delivered? Really? Where the heck are these scones baked? I thought this was a bakery. 

After about a ten minute wait, several trays of four different kinds of scones arrived. They had raisin, cinnamon raisin, almond, and almond poppy seed. No Bailey's Irish Cream or chocolate chip scones. To my disappointment, the scones were not the same as those served at Lovejoy's. The scones were just your average scones. They were dry, not fresh, light and fluffy like those found at Lovejoy's. They definitely needed a schmear of jam and Double Devon Cream. 

Unfortunately, thanks to John Campbell's I'm reminded why I wasn't a big fan of scones in the first place (before Lovejoy's). I think I'll stick to my French pastries. It's all good.
author: Anastasia B.

description:
I am in love with the baked goods at this place.  These have got to be the best scones that I've ever tasted in my life. 

I purchased: Irish Bailey's Cream Scone. Two Shortbread Cookies, and Mince Puffs. 

The Mince Puffs were amazing!  They were flakey and flavorful.  Mmm...

The Shortbread Cookies tasted like pre-crystal sugars.  I wouldn't get these again. 

I will definitely be back to try the rest of backed goods here!  I am curious about their Bacon, Brie, and Mushroom Bread!  I had a small sample and it seems to be good!
author: Brenda T.

description:
John Cambell's Irish Bakery - 5625 Geary (between 20th x 21st) ...had a delicious scone and a Irish Sausage Pastie from the place a few months ago - the scone was $2 and the Pastie was $5 - this pastie is delicious, rich, and the 2 items were plenty to feed 2 people breakfast with coffee or tea.

The pastie was not all that impressive to look at - but the quality of it, perfectly seasoned and baked, was really fantastic.
author: Susan B.

description:
Yes, I agree.  I've loved mostly everything I've tried.  They've got the best scones.  Soft and moist to the touch; but even better when consumed.

My favorite scone is the chocolate chip scone.  Today I bought a dozen various scones with #13 thrown in for free.  Bought the chocolate chip, the raspberry chcolate chip, the blueberry, and the Bailey's today.  They only make the Bailey's Irish cream scones on the weekend.

Their Irish soda bread is also very good. Especially if heated in the toaster oven first.

I can only recall one previous time where I bought a cookie that I didn't care for.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I didn't think it was possible to love this place even more than my first visit in March for the beloved St. Paddy's Day. My gals and I celebrated Cinco de Mayo next door at Blarney Stone (read here as to why we chose the Blarney over a Mexican restaurant http://www.yelp.com/biz/blarney-stone-san-francisco#hrid:G6zalY7sRVbBGEaonWhNZw) and feeling buzzed and ready to nosh, we stopped in John Campbell's Irish Bakery for some tasty Irish treats! We were the only customers at the time, and thank goodness, since we took forever to decide what to get. Thankfully, the staffers were patient and entertained a friend who popped in with a sombrero (obviously celebrating Cinco de Mayo the proper way). We wanted to get every single baked treat, but opted for and quite literally inhaled the following: 

- Chicken and veggie pastie: So tasty and served warm! I loved the flakiness of the pastie and wasn't soggy at all. The filling consisted of hearty pieces of chicken with peas, potatoes, carrots. It wasn't dry and incredibly savory! 

- Apple Tart: I love that their tarts are mini, so saves on the caloric intake. Anywho, I had to get something sweet to go along with my savory pastie. This was amazing, and you have a choice between a regular or crumb apple tart. The crumb one is sweeter, and loved how rich and appley the filling was. A lovely sweet treat! 

- Chicken Curry Pastie: Dalane ordered this and loved it, and concluded that it was like my pastie but with a curry sauce, which had a nice kick! 

- Fruit Scone: Dalane and I shared this, as she isn't much of a sweet tooth (or so she says)! This had a wonderful glazed layer on top of the scone, which was not dry and had ample amounts of fruit and nuts! Yum! 

- Turkey Sandwich: Amy ordered this, and was so huge that she only ate half and saved the other for lunch. She absolutely loved the sammie, too! 

Upon my return to JCIB, next on my list to try is the Belfast Bap and chocolate cherry bread. I have to space out my JCIB visits so I won't gain too much weight from these Irish goodies!
author: Gill C.

description:
My boyfriend and I have been living in the area where this bakery is just about a year already.  The first few times we've stopped in this bakery, the shelves seemed so bare and empty.  When we first stumbled upon this bakery, we got a few basic items such as scones, griddles and pastries, but that's all they had left.  They were REALLY good but had nothing much to offer.

Almost a year went by and we hadn't stopped in to check out their baked items until NOW!  We were walking by tonight and peeked in their window and saw their shelves full of goodies.  When we walked in, it was like Christmas!  Their shelves were stocked with ALL sorts of stuff, so we stocked up never knowing if we'd ever see this bakery like this ever again. We stocked up on some griddles, apple puffs, bread, potato bread and a roast beef sandwich.  The guy at the counter was REALLY nice and helpful and when I mentioned to him that I've NEVER seen this store so stocked up before, he gave us some good tips...

Thursdays are the worst days because they make minimal items since it's considered end of the work week.  The best days are usually starting from either Saturday or Sunday on and then dies down again around Wednesdays.  So don't go on FRIDAYS like we did in the beginning!

Oh, and EVERYTHING is good there!  Two thumbs WAY UP!!!!
author: Holly L.

description: Stepping into John Campbell's Irish bakery is like repeating my trip to Ireland. Delicious treats and great, scrumptious  grub to keep me satisfied and warm all year around. Many of my favorites have sold out before I get there! My favorite is John's irresistible seasonal Christmas cake or plum pudding. Oh my goodness, it's the best!  Thank you John, for being in the neighborhood and treating us to the best of Ireland.
author: Artemis R.

description:
CASH ONLY! 

Really love the employees here - always very sweet. Once, one of them even gave me a couple of cookies on the house! They get 5 stars.

I've noticed that recently, they have been selling charred goods. In particular, the last two times I bought snowballs from them, they have been dry and definitely burned. Expecting delicious, moist raspberry jam confectionary heaven and getting a mouthful of charcoal? That made me sad enough that I probably won't go back. Maybe the scones are better, but those looked burned on the bottom too.
author: Diane Y.

description:
What happened??  My lovely little local bakery is going down the tubes.

Veggie roll is clearly days old, hard as a brick.  I ask for milk for coffee and counter girl points to half n' half calling it milk then says they have none.

Also - she desperately needed her calculator to figure out the $10 I gave her for a $3.50 item.  Gave me the wrong change.

The samples were stale and crumbs were everywhere.  The racks were near empty and some of the food had fallen off the trays and were sadly slumped against the glass.

WHAT IS GOING ON OVER THERE?
author: Marcy M.

description:
If you like great scones, Irish soda bread, shepherds pie and pasties, John Campbell's is a great place to know about.

But what I really like are their fruit and custard tarts.

It's small, unassuming and very Irish.  

Sweet, savory, fairly priced, and tasty, hearty fare on a foggy day.  Can't get much better than that!
author: Liz S.

description: My English mother came for Christmas this year-- I had the plum pudding, but no mince pies. (I'm talking about the individual-portion sized pies, not a full sized pie.) She had already rejected the mince pies at another nearby bakery because of the suboptimal crust-to-filling ratio. I called this bakery, ordered a dozen, good move. My mother said they were among the best she'd ever had. This from a woman who normally makes her own-- and certainly would not have held back if she felt they were subpar in any way. Thank you Mr. John Campbell, whoever you are.
author: Sarah M.

description: After almost twenty years in the states.  This is first bakery I have found brown bread for my smoked salmon.  Also the first shop I have found with sausage rolls :)
author: Kieran R.

description:
Cute little place nearby work.....with the most AMAZING scones!

I'm not normally, ever actually, a scones sort of gal. I feel they're dense, hard, dry, and sometimes tasteless. Even at nice establishments for high tea, it's the same deal. You would have to slather it in butter or jam, to have it not dry out your mouth. bleeecccch!!
