Why on earth then, did I decide to try ones here? I walked past the storefront, saw them on display, and kept walking like many times before. This time, I turned back for some odd reason, as if someone was beckoning me, and decided to give them a go again. 

Omyword! These are scrumptious, soft, tasty --wudchabelieveit?!? scones! Once you've had these, you'll turn up your noses at all others lol. Maybe scones are meant to be hard, dense and dry, but I'm sure liking these treats instead!

Wish they had more variety tho, and unfortunately that day, they were out of soda bread.
author: Ly T.

description:
This pretty little bakery is located a bit outside the city center, but honestly, a trip over here for their chocolate scones is so much worth it. Super fresh baked goods and great breads, with a lot of samples to try.

I just wished they have some seats so that I could go there for a fika (coffee+pastry=fika in Sweden) too.
author: Linn L.

description:
This place is amazing.  Not only do they have the tastiest treats, they have the nicest employees who actually care about people.  I went in the other day to get lunch, and I mentioned to the girl that I was going to get something to give the homeless man outside the bakery.  When she charged me, she hooked it up on the pizza slice I had picked for him.  So kind!!!  

Oh, and I tried the potato bread with brie and bacon in it...holy moly, it was like a chunk of heaven right in my mouth.
author: Terika T.

description:
Everything here is excellent. Truly authentic! Scones and soda bread sell out quick so get there early!

Cash only, FYI.
author: Mike F.

description:
Been driving down Geary every day for the better part of 8 months. Never paid much attention to this bakery. 

But then in a recent search for all things Irish I stumbled upon this gem on Yelp. 

Five words for you: light fluffy Irish scones delish!
Oh OK, six more words for you: corned beef sandwich with cheddar cheese

Pleasant morning faces to greet ya'. Next time I stop in it's the Shepherd's pie that I'm trying. 

The scones were so good that I started speakin' with an Irish tongue! Though my Irish friends tell me I sound worse than Tom Cruise in Far and Away.
author: Stephanie I.

description: I lived in Ireland for a time. I miss Irish food. They have Irish soda bread! I forgot how much I missed it. Prices are average. Food is good. I will go there again the next time I am in San Francisco.
author: Jack N.

description: The bakery has some great breads and pastries, rich pasties and the Breakfast in Bread is genius. The only sad part is that the morning sandwich (Belfast bap) I love but never have time to ask them to heat up, will sometimes be frozen in the middle.., I know the sandwiches can't always be warm, but ice crystals in my eggs are a bummer :(
author: Allie D.

description:
Man the potato bread here is "AMAZING."  I really hesitate to use that word too because it's so misapplied.  I usually want to slam people when they say it.  "Oh, that Diet Coke you got at McDonald's yesterday was "AMAZING?"  Really?  A Diet f***ing Coke?  It caused you great wonder or surprise?  That's funny Diet Coke just causes me to burp a lot.   Try looking up the definition once.   

If you want to really understand how to use it, go to John Campbell's Irish Bakery and load up on some potato bread.  You'll experience great wonder at how savory it is and surprise that you can't stop eating it.  It's addictive like crack.  That my foolish friends is how you use "AMAZING."
author: Brian K.

description:
With a noticeable honest-to-goodness Irish population in the Outer Richmond/Sunset, and plenty of authentic pubs to prove it, you have to ask: where's the Irish food?  Ok, so maybe boiled beef brisket and cabbage isn't very commercial (though don't knock it till you've tried it).  But if you've ever had Irish soda bread you'll know that the emerald isle's baked goods could be wildly popular here.  Thankfully, Campbell's Irish Bakery (a spin-off of the Blarney Stone?) has come along to fill the void.

The selection here is small but perfect: naturally you'll want to get 5 of the best scones in the city for $5, and a belfast bap breakfast sandwich (with eggs, irish bacon and sausage--like a McMuffin, only made of real food).  There's also plenty of breads you can take home and turn into sandwiches or desserts, like Bara Brith.  Only downside is there's nowhere to sit, so if you're too hungry to wait till you get home, well, you can always try to nab one of those outdoor tables at Peet's (or maybe they'll let you eat at the pub if it's open?).
author: Wes M.

description:
** Get here when they open at 7 AM for scones hot out of the oven **

I uploaded 14 photos.  Here's the run down:

- scones (chocolate / blueberry / Baileys): They are OK, but they don't really stand on their own: much like a bicsuit, they really need butter or jam.  The chocolate is the best, but the "chocolate thing" sold at Arizmendi bakery is way better.

- Brown bread: an earthy, crumbly bread, but it definitely needs jam or butter; it also doesn't stand on its own.

- Chocolate cherry bread: very good, and addictive.

- Potato bread: Very unusual; really strong potato flavor, with a chewy (al dente) potato texture.  Great with jam.

- Cheese/Garlic bread loaf: Really good.  Very light and fluffy inside, with a great taste of garlic and cheese.

- Apple tart: it's way too mushy: it's just a pile of mush.

- Focaccia roll: It's OK.

- Square focaccia: I tried the veggie.  It's excellent,  with just enough grease content to make it really savory.

- Chocolate whiskey truffle balls: very good.

The stout coffee lives up to its name.

In summary: I'd go back for the Chocolate cherry bread, Cheese/Garlic bread loaf, potato bread, square focaccia, and chocolate whiskey balls.
author: Scott F.

description:
CASH ONLY!  After Bay to Breakers we were hungry so I suggested John Campbell's Irish Bakery.  It's someplace I've been wanting to try and it's in the Richmond neighborhood where we were anyways.

It's a small bakery with no seating area.  It's a take-out place.  

I picked out:
Belfast bap: Irish bacon, Irish sausage, scrambled egg & cheddar cheese all in a bap $5.  Like a egg mac muffin, but better.  I liked the sausage the best.  Bread & everything else was fine.  

Beef pastie $4.5: it's huge!  We got one & shared it.  Ground beef mixed w/ peas, carrots, onions, & a gravy sauce in a flaky puff pastry.  

Also got a loaf of Irish brown bread $5. It's a round loaf that tasted very salty & like cornbread.  Dry & crumbly.  Just ok for me, husband liked it.

My total $14.50.  CASH ONLY.

Lady that helped me was very nice, and asked if we wanted the food heated - we did for the first 2 items.

We ate the food at the Blarney Stone Pub that's next door - heard they own it too.

Hrs:
Sun-Sat 7am-8pm
author: Ann L.

description:
This is a hit-and-miss kind of place. Most times the food is fresh, but sometimes it's been sitting there for a while. 
They're constantly increasing their prices without updating their signs. Ask before you order.
The guys behind the counter are ALWAYS friendly, and amicable.
author: Carlos G.

description:
I abandoned my cabbage soup diet for this place. 

Raisin Scone: I had a mouth-gasm, over and over again.
Chocolate chip Scone: pretty good, but raisin win
Short bread cookies: HOLY BEEP. so amazing 
Girdle cake: HOLY BEEP BEEP BEEP. 

i'm going to go in the morning next time to get some warm raisin scones in my mouf!!!!!
author: Emily T.

description:
The Irish breakfast is humongous; sausage so moist and juicy, that when you cut it, the oil just burbles out. All in all, merely ok tasting.
My buddy is Irish and at 285 pounds capable. He enjoyed it and could not finish all of his Irish breakfast.
author: Bert K.

description: Good baked goods! Stopped by on my way home from work and I was so hungry that I was ready to eat anything. I got this doughy potato veggie thing that was pretty good. Price is right and the fact that they can heat stuff up is awesome. Good hours and they take credit cards.
author: Yolanda Y.

description: Bought some scones here on a beautiful Friday morning. The lady here was so nice and I was happy to spend some $$ on Geary Blvd.
author: Kevin L.

description:
The Choc Chip Scone was out of this world! as was the Irish Choc eclair.
The tea cookies were AWESOME!! I accidentally found this place driving by and insisted my husband stop because I an IRISH ! I will be taking some home next time I go! I am coming back to San Fran ( I live in Sacramento) just to visit the bakery!!! You will not be sorry you visited here!
author: kristin r.

description:
We made the trek out from CCC after years of wanting to visit this place.  I'm glad we did.  The gal who helped us was a doll.  She cooked up a Belfast Bap for me to eat while we were picking the rest of our items.  She special bagged everything we bought so it wouldn't get damp in the cooler we brought.  The food?  We worked our way through our purchases over the next week and I'm happy to report that everything was topnotch.  I especially loved the sausage rolls.  My son loved the pork pies.  

Warning - get there early!  We were there by about 8AM on a Saturday morning so they were fully stocked.  By the time we were done, there were two people in line waiting to stock up, too.   If everyone buys like we do, everything must be gone before noon!
author: Marie N.

description:
Super tasty baked goods. I come for the savories more than the sweets (I'm not a big scone fan, and the cookies are good, but less to my taste - which isn't the bakery's fault, just my own pickiness). The sausage rolls are so tasty, with a nice flaky pastry around them. The girl working the counter convinced me to try the chicken curry sausage roll, and it is ah-mazing. 

My personal crack is the Belfast Bap. Loads of sausage, irish bacon, and egg in a nice crusty bread. It's hardening my arteries just thinking about it, but I could live off this particular breakfast sandwich.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I love this bakery. I found it by accident -- just walking about and ran into it. Peeking through the store front glass, I couldn't resist the temptations that awaited me inside. 

I almost went nuts -- they all look so good and the prices are very reasonable. 

I took home chocolate chip scones, Bailey's scones, chocolate cherry bread, beef pastries and a Shepard's pie. Oh, they were so good. It's tough to stop eating them, as long as they are within my easy reach. 

It's worth a trip to the Richmond district. 

The staff are very friendly and patient. It's great to be reminded of my trip to Ireland years ago. 

A lovely place that hearkens back to the good old days.
author: Peace L.

description:
The snowballs are what Darwin would claim, "the aspect of you that makes you unable to be a survivor of the fittest" because it makes me blind of all dangerous obstacles around me.  They have me hypnotised: "I have to eat the snowball scone, I have to eat it, yum! yum! yum!"

Coming to John Campbell's is clearly a form of psychiatric therapy for me.

Irish Style Scones are just down right ummalicious.
author: Tony U.

description: Pastries were delicious and at good prices, the people were polite and friendly. It's tiny but don't let that fool you. I'd love to come back to try some of their breads and the fabled scones too.
author: Alex K.

description: Have been buying my favorites for years...soda bread, raisin scones, shepherd's pie, snowballs & holiday pudding!!!!!  Today tasted the sample corned beef slice.  I would not have bought, but after tasting, I bought.  Grandson came home between jobs & ate.  He said it is one of the best things he has eaten.  There is quite a bit left.  I love that there are samples & almost always there is something new to me.  The staff are always helpful & friendly.
author: Tj A.

description:
Their scones are lighter than air!  I usually do not eat scones due to its dense, dry texture.  However, my sister bought some home and these were the best scones I've ever eaten.  I've tried the blueberry and chocolate chip scones.  They do not skimp on the blueberries and choco chips!  

For the price of 5 scones for $5, their prices can't be beat either!  Definitely give them a try!
author: Wendy H.

description: Bought cones for a friend and embarrassed to have brought day old, dry scones over.  At the opening, baked goods were fresh. Not so much anymore.
author: Laurie R.

description:
I walked by this place TWICE before I realized where it was. Ironically I found it when I wasn't looking for it.
Murphy's Law I tell ya.
ANYWAY....
upon walking in, you are assailed by warm doughy smells and the smiling face of a pretty red-headed young woman who is eager to help.

So many choices! I thought to myself.
But I finally settled on some of the "pasties" (pronounced " PAH-Steez" NOT "pay-stees" like those twirly things strippers and girls trying to impress boyfriends put on their nipples--oh snap, can I write nipple on Yelp??). I partook of the chicken veggies, and the chicken curry pasties..and WOW...delicious!!!!!
The curry was spicy like I like it, and the breaded part was buttery and flakey like I like it too.

I recommend their brown bread which brought back memories of travelling in the Emerald Isle myself and having brown bread and real butter on cold mornings with my tea.
author: Kathy K.

description:
Stumbled upon this place & glad I did.  Been dropping in for the yummy, reasonably priced scones which are available in a few flavors.  Wish the split pea soup was available daily since it's hearty & delicious.

Need to drop by around lunch for the Belfast Bap.  Glad it is a long walk from my place so I can earn/burn off the treats.
author: Kim S.

description:
We loved this spot. 

We tried a raspberry tart, the potato bread, and the blueberry scones. All was so good!

I've never had scones so light and fluffy. It's how I imagined them to always be when made properly. I didn't grow up with my mother cooking a lot, but also being from California I doubt she would have cooked scones.

The prices are fantastic and the food is wonderful. I can't wait to go back to try more!
author: Marlene T.

description:
Awesome + Delicious = FANTASTIC!!!!!!!!

 Your staff is knowledgeable, friendly,  and your products are truly of the highest caliber. EXCELLENT scones, soda breads, pasties (the food variety),  rolls, sandwiches, and snow balls(again, the food type).

   I look forward to regular  visits to John Campbell's Irish Bakery and the ensuing 2 mile swims and five mile runs to work off the calories!

  Many Thanks for opening a bakery that is a true treasure!
author: Richard T.

description:
$6 for 6 chocolate chip scones, with lots of chocolate chips in them.  

Always friendly staff.
author: daphne w.

description:
Yup, I'm coming back. It started out with friends telling me about their awesome scones, and yes they're delightful. Not like the candy-sugar-crusted variety you'll get at Peet's up the street, or Starbucks down the street, these scones have a lighter, fluffier texture and don't feel so rock-hard heavy.

It's self serve, which is kinda nice, just pick and choose what you like. At first I was going to do two, then I thought maybe four, but then realized that buying six was the same price as buying four.  And I don't regret it one bit.

Raisin, chocolate chip, plain, and blueberry. Tried them all. The raisin and chocolate chip were both a little sweeter, and hence, had a little more flavor. But they were all pretty good.

A little surprise on the way out was the stacks of self-serve samples. I took a Trader Joe's sized cup of pork pie, thinking, "Meh, it's just a sample, how good can it be?" Even that was freaking good. Rich pastry with a chunk of pork sausage.

Looks like I'm gonna have something else to buy the next time I'm back.

Along with a scone, of course.
author: Tony L.

description: I love this place! Customer service is always soooo great! and the pastries are delicious! Definitely one to check out :)
author: Fran M.

description:
I'm super Irish.  

That being said, it's very hard for my to get baked goods like my Nan makes here in the states.  I'd worry for myself and my womanly figure if not for John Campbell's.

I go once every couple of weeks to pick up a piece of the tomato mushroom focaccia and either a scone, cream puff or eclair.  

Now, when I brought home a piece of focaccia to my boyfriend, he asked me if that was what Irish food is like.  

The answer is no.  It's not.  Irish food is bland and definitely not savory.  However, American food is.  John Campbell's mixes the slightly drier bread with the tasty toppings to make something that appeals to everyone.

The scones are a little on the dry side, which is how the Irish make scones, so that's right on point.

Cash only, I believe.
author: Aishling R.

description: I walk by here all the time and I never have been in, only walking past and letting my eyes glaze over and my mouth water. On a whim, I finally went in. I bought a rhubarb crumble tart and just had to yelp that it was the best rhubarb baked good I have ever had. It wasn't super cheap but the experience of my Sunday afternoon indulgence was well worth the cost.
author: Cassie C.

description:
We always stop by when we are walking our four legged friend...it never lets us down. Try the amazing coconut snowballs, the chocolate chip scones, the mini apple tart, the custard tart,,,,and many more.

And if this is not enough they have a great pub next door....a pint and a pastie......yummmm.

The folks here are super nice and the place is just amazing ....give it  a try.
author: David G.

description: What is it about this place? There are so many fabulous bakeries in SF... like seriously amazing places that blow this disappointment out of the water! No comparison. They use way too much baking soda in their scones... why are they always so salty? And why are the girls silly and inattentive? Just wondering... I don't like this place and am saddened that it's still open. But hey... shorter lines are truly delicious places...
author: Irina S.

description:
shepard's pie (minced meat mush with vegetables topped with browned creamy mashed potatoes) made me break my 10 year streak of not cussing. f&%$ing delicious. i closed my eyes and found myself in those old school medieval times where chickens run around women that have missing teeth. i've never tasted any other shepard's pie so i'm no expert, but for me, it's love at first taste. 

i want to convert religions so shepard can fill me in on the family secret.... or maybe i can ani-morp into a sheep. see you soon sweetie pie.


2 in the morning.. fantasizing about food...wow, i feel like a teenager in love. hahahah.
author: Katherine F.

description: Great customer service and amazing Irish Soda bread. What else can you ask for?
author: Al O.

description:
I've been to John Campbell's many times in the past and I have finally learned which items to buy and which items to skip. 

Do buy the almond shortbread cookies, the tea cookies, the soda bread, the potato bread, the brown bread and the rhubarb tart. In essence, buy any and all of the baked goods. The cookies are buttery and delicious. The potato bread and the brown bread are soft, crusty and perfectly savory. And the soda bread is absolutely fantastic just like any Irish grandmother would have made.

However, the other day I decided to have lunch at John Campbell's Irish Bakery. I ordered the corned beef and cabbage sandwich, which sounded so much better than it turned out to be. The brown bread was delicious but there was too much flavorless cabbage and only two meager slices of corned beef. Overall, not a satisfying lunch. Worst of all, the service can be needlessly rude.

I will go back to John Campbell's to continue buying their delicious breads, but I will not be heading back for lunch items. Live and learn, I suppose.
author: Stephanie H.

description: The Shepherds pies (both curry and regular) are to die for, as is the open faced sandwich and the pasties. One of my go-to places in the neighborhood.
author: Gopnik M.

description:
A delicious little bakery full of a variety of sweet and savory goodies!  They have scones, focaccia, Irish soda bread, potato bread, brown bread, little tarts, meat and veggie pasties, and different kinds of sandwiches.  I bought a yummy chicken and veggie pasty, basically a meat pie/ Irish version of a calzone, with a buttery, flaky crust.  The pasty was quite large and was only $5.  They did not skimp on the filling which had peas, potatoes, carrots, and big, tender chunks of chicken.  I would definitely go back and try some of the other pasty flavors.

My husband got the corned beef and cabbage sandwich (a good-sized sandwich for $6) which he enjoyed but wished it was a bit warmer (they heat up any of the sandwiches and pasties upon request).  Although he thought the sandwich needed more corned beef and less cabbage, he really liked the bread which was thick, crusty, and dense.

We also shared a couple of scones, chocolate chip and Bailey's Irish cream  ($1.50 per scone or $6 for half dozen).  Their scones are different from other scones I've tried: they are more bready, they don't have a crunchy, sugary top, and they are not as dry.  But they were still tasty and a nice change from what you're used to.  The chocolate chip scone was definitely not lacking in chips, and the Irish cream flavor really shone through in the Bailey's scone, yet was not over powering.  I am really glad that I've found a bakery to satisfy both my sweet and savory cravings.
author: Ailene M.

description:
As good as it gets, YES!

One bite of brown bread and I was transported straight to Ireland. John Campbell imports his ingredients from the Isle and you can tell. The raspberry almond tart and mince pastry were so tasty that I wish I came home with a dozen more. Lovely people work there.

(OK, so a few days later, I went to the 21st st location and did come home with several more, and they weren't as good as the first time. Should have tried an apple pie, also...)

Perfection. and no credit cards...

Cheers~
author: Heather N.

description:
My corned beef & cabbage sandwich had mold! I was too far away from the bakery to bring it back and complain.

I still enjoy the baked goods, but I've been sort of scared of the sandwiches ever since.
author: Stacy J.

description:
Still good despite the 25cent increase so it breaks down to this:

$1.75 per scone or $7.00 for 6... (all I got was one scone out of my first day of cardio walking T_T)

and to those who poo poo this bakery, maybe if you'd try every bakery in SF, you'd realize that the fluffy varieties JC have in the morning, and I do mean MORNING...will more than prove that JC's makes scones as awesome as possible.  Don't throw stones at my scones!
author: Pauline L.

description: The 2nd location is great and the staff is super friendly and helpful.  My favorites are the scones, belfast bap, brown bread, and cinnamon/sugar griddle cakes ;D
author: Tiff T.

description:
Loved loved loved this place and they totally totally let me down :{

Called over a week ago to place a special order of 2 dozen Bailey's Irish Cream scones as a present for my parents whom I was flying out to visit. 

They talked to their bakers and confirmed the order, the day I was suppose to pick it up! No scones! The order never got made it the bakers. What a waste of my time! 

Super bummed.
author: S ..

description:
This place is excellent! Went there just this morning and the staff was so sweet, I felt right at home, set my baby on the floor to play while picking out my sweet and savory pastries for the week! 

My husband's Australian, and very similar style of bake shops are all over Sydney and I knew he'd LOVE everything I brought home.

He did love it all indeed, great, GREAT sausage rolls, meat pasties were so good. We also got some of the cream and jam scones, shortbread cookies for my tea, and some snowballs for dessert I have yet to try. Can't wait! 

PLEEZ come to the East Bay in downtown Walnut Creek! You will have lines out the door!!!
author: Devon F.

description: I enjoyed the raisin scone, like a mini Irish soda bread. I can't wait to return.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description:
Wow, these Irish folks can bake!
 
My nieces love the scones and cookies there, we also tried the heavenly brittle bread -deliciously done and great texture.  The chocolate cherry bread is a mouthful of chocolate and cherry with 
every bite.  This bread will go great with coffee.

Yummy, no credit card at this bakery, but stay away if you are on a diet :)
author: Raymond N.

description:
I was in the area and was craving some oatmeal chocolate chip cookie and a foccacia. I went inside and saw that there was nobody there, and was reminded by a sign that they were a CASH ONLY place.All good, so I go to Chase next door to get some cash, and came back. Good there was people in there when I got back. It turns out that the lady earlier was just kind of hiding behind the counter, probably snobbing herself out or something. Regardless, I went ahead and got a bag and a pair of tongs (since it is help yourself) then started to look for those cookies. She was finally not busy, so I asked her "s'cuse me, do you happen to have the oatmeal chocolate chip cookies?" She gave me a "wtf are you talking about" look and said "we don't sell chocolate chip cookies here."

 I felt the tension and said thanks, and just got what I needed. When I was ready to make a choice of what foccacia I wanted, she ended up helping someone else when I was in line and was trying to get her attention. Great. I'm optimistic, because I loved this bakery so much. It only took me 10 minutes to get her attention before she could get what I needed and ring me up. I can't bring myself to knock them down more than one star. I probably just came across a cranky cashier, but I've had better experiences here. I'll still go back, but I won't deal with a crankky cashier. 
Ps: I can guarantee that they've sold oatmeal chocolate chip cookies there. She tweakin.
author: Monina C.

description:
Delicious, fresh scones and a good chance of running into an expat Irish cutie.  4 stars, my friends, 4 stars.

P.S. If you are a male Irish cutie, I make even better scones than this place.  *Mae West voice* "Come up and see me sometime."
author: MakeUp M.

description: Next time I'm in SF I need to go back to get a Belfast Bap.  I'm salivating now just thinking about what a monster of a breakfast sandwich it is.  Great breakfast to keep you going all day.  Make sure you have something heroic planned though, otherwise you'll just collapse in a delicious food coma.
author: shawn g.

description:
Yay, they took over the old video store space. We randomly walked by last night on the way to dinner and were drawn in by the delicious looking breads and scones in their window.  Besides baked goods, they also have a few knick knacks such as Irish branded ketchup and candies in their store.  The set up is very similar to the Geary Street location and I had their raisin scone this morning for breakfast - delicious. It was not too flaky and help up in my toaster over.  

Their soda breads looked yummy as well as their focaccia.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I've waited for 10 years to taste what a "real" european scone tastes like, ever since I was regaled with stories of the non-sweet, biscuity wonder of the supposed non-american scone.

They're good - and apparently more popular in the states than I thought.  Not sweet, tastes just like a light biscuit, and just a bit sour from the baking soda - would be great with a nice dark tea. I also got a sample of the delightful Irish brown bread, made with imported wheat.
author: Shinny L.

description:
Placed an order a week ahead of time for 2 dozen scones. Placed the order in person and watched the man behind the counter write it down. When we drove across town in the pouring rain to pick them up the day before Saint Patrick's Day they tell us there is no order and not a scone in the place at 11:30 am. 

The baking is clearly done somewhere else as the people in the store have no ability to put a batch in the oven. By 11:30 am the day before Saint Patrick's Day you shouldn't be sold out of every Irish item - you are an Irish bakery!!

The baked items are good but I will never spend another dime here. I see from other reviews that they have done the same thing to others. Get your act together - how can you run a business this way?
author: Julia S.

description:
My wallet hates this place but my stomach loves it! Since moving down the street from this bakery, I've been signing away a little bit of my paycheck to John Campbell's Irish Bakery every week. My absolute favorite baked good there is the plain griddle bread. Soft and doughy, like a donut that you don't feel so guilty about eating (though the guiltier cinnamon and sugar version is just as delicious). 

Other picks include rhubarb tarts, any of the veggie/meat filled pasties, blueberry scones, brown bread, and soda bread. I'm slowly making my way through their list of goodies. Certain items aren't available at times (many an early morning I've wished for griddle bread and many a morning I've happily settled for scones instead). Buying one or two items isn't too expensive but it's hard not to want to buy everything in sight which will leave your wallet empty and your belly bulging.
author: Tony S.

description:
Today (8/26) would have been my best friend Erin's 39th birthday (for the second or third year), had she not passed away a few years ago. Needless to say, she's been on my mind all day. But as usual, I managed to pretend that she's off having adventures in NYC or LA, as she was wont to do--and we simply hadn't had time to catch up in a while. ;)

But when I was in the Richmond this foggy evening to appease my hunger for dim sum and roast duck, I got a bit of a wake up call. I didn't think anything could stop me from my mission--but John Campbell's Irish Bakery did. Stopped me dead in my tracks, it did. 

The green storefront with a window display full of baked goods suddenly brought back memories of the time Erin and I took a 17-hour ferry ride from France to Ireland just for the hell of it. It was the first time she'd visited the country of her ancestors, and though our stay was brief, we met some colorful characters and had an amazingly fun time, as we always did.

When I stepped inside the bakery, I encountered another display of baked goods, both savory and sweet. There were several types of pasties and shepherd's pie, along with sweets like cream-filled scones and various fruit tarts. I selected the beef pastie and a rhubarb tart to go. The pastie--which was ground beef in a flavorful gravy with carrots and peas encased in a flaky half-moon crust--was perfect for the cool evening. And the rhubarb tart, with a buttery sugared crust in the shape of a shamrock, was a wonderful balance of tart and sweet.

If I'd had time, I would have loved to have stopped next door at The Blarney Stone to raise a pint of Guinness to Erin. But I think there will be other opportunities for that whenever I'm in the Richmond. :)

Erin go bragh!
author: Julie K.

description: Irish Scones FTW! I love just the regular raisin scone, definitely the best of them all!
author: Nicole L.

description:
Bloody brilliant.
Veggie & Chicken pasties (curry) are both excellent, as is the shepherd's pie.
Soda bread's quite good, guinness bread is tasty.   Warm it up and walk it next door to Blarney Stone and have a pint.
Don't forget the HP sauce.
author: Graham W.

description: An incredibly small place packed with lots of goodies. Scones are wonderful, and the pasties are great ( although I prefer lots of gravy on top ).
author: George T.

description:
I swear I must live on the raspberry and apricot tea cookies. They're my daily vitamins. My bf and I have a passion for this place and are definitely regulars and know the staff by name. 

Everything we've eaten here is fresh, buttery, and filling. One word: YUM.
author: Kira B.

description:
It's weird that this place is in the Marina since I actually like going here. They've been my go-to bakery the past few weeks for snacks or a weekend breakfast pastry. My goal is to try everything at least once and I'm well on my way after a few visits already. Do not miss the small tarts behind the glass at the counter - all of them are amazing and a perfectly small size. 

Prices are good I think. They really are open until late evenings even on Sunday which is fantastic ~ because sometimes I'm craving a blueberry scone at 9pm OK?
author: Chris M.

description:
A coworker had lots of praise for the Irish Bakery and said that the fresh made muffins (or scones) with real whipped cream are outstanding. 

Well, she surprised me at work yesterday with not only fresh blueberry muffins but two wonderful loaves of bread. 

The muffins were so good and there were blueberries mixed throughout the entire muffin. And the muffins were large, not small. Oh so delicious! 

The bread she bought was more like a dessert, so delightful and such a treat. It was like something one gets for a holiday. Really a nice surprise! 

One of the two loaves she bought was John Campbell's version of the traditional "Panatone"-like Italian bread. Only his version is all fresh, rich and full of flavor. 

And the other loaf was more like a pastry, rather than a bread. It is the almond-marzipan loaf. Oh so good! It is made with fresh toasted almonds and a luxuriously home made marzipan (or almond paste). 

So good! These breads are really works of art and I can see why the bakery has become very popular.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Great Irish bakery! I've never been to the original location in Richmond, so am glad they opened a new branch closer to where I live.

They had lots of samples available, which was fantastic as I was able to try a wide variety of their baked goods before deciding what to pick up. Ended up buying dark chocolate cherry soda bread, a chocolate almond tart, and a blueberry scone w/ whipped cream and jam. All very good, although I wish they used clotted cream instead of whipped cream on the scone.

No seating available - not a huge deal but would have been nice to be able to sit down and enjoy baked goods w/ coffee there. Also, FYI, they don't accept credit cards.

Will come again if/when in the area.
author: Gary Y.

description: The things there were good, but sometimes theywere out everything, so, sometimes i was desappointed when i got there and they didnt have the good stuff.
author: Danielle S.

description: Their scones are really tender. They are more plain and simple than the ones at Arizmendi's, which I like. 6 for $6! Cash only. Their danishes with strawberry are just the right amount of sweetness, the jam filling tastes homemade. We weren't too crazy about the chocolate banana danish (mushy and one hard piece of chocolate). I would definitely come back.
author: Carissa C.

description:
Dangerous....stay away if you fear carbs and delicious goodness.

Tasty baked goods from savory to sweet. Pass by every day and beautiful apricot tea cookies and chocolate snowballs call my name. They say,  "F*&! carbs. Screw calories!"

The only thing holding this girl back from gaining a hundred pounds on John Campbell's baked goods alone is the clever built-in portion control mechanism whereby you can purchase just one delicious apple tart, scone, tea cookie or whatever you please. 

Love this place so much I considered writing it a limerick, but that would have taken away from apple tart consuming time.
author: Pha L.

description:
An essential stop every time my girlfriend and I visit the city. We always make the half-hour bus ride from the BART on the 38 just for John Campbell's!

We've tried a lot of the breads, cookies, sandwiches, and sweets by now. I'll go through the foods we've tried in a list...

Apple Puffs: These are the most amazing bits of baked heaven on Earth ever!!! If I'm making a trip down to the Richmond District just for John Campbell's, I always call to make sure they have them in that day... the apple filling is light and delicious, and the pastry is to-die-for. Flaky on the outside, chewy and moist on the inside, lightly coated with crunchy sugar... it makes for all sorts of amazing chewing sensations to go along with the divine taste. Oh god apple puffs, I miss them already.

Mince Puffs: Same pastry as the apple puffs, but I find the filling a little too strong for me. They add some spices and dried fruit for this puff; not my thing, but I think that's a matter of taste.

Raisin soda bread: $5 loaf of slightly sweet, delicious soda bread littered with raisins that makes for a few great breakfasts. Mmmmm.

Potato bread: I haven't seen this the last few times I've been, but these slices of savory potato-flavored bread were really tasty. A good addition to a lunch or dinner.

Scones: Yumm! Delicious and fresh. They have a really satisfying consistency to bite into, and are flavored just right. Not buttery or dense, but a little bit lighter and breadier. I like the style :)

Cookies: The shortbread cookies I've gotten have all been buttery and delicious. The small ones are usually a quarter each and are great little snacks, just the right amount of sweetness, and great buttery flavor. Mmmm.

Shepherd's Pie: Great on a cold day. They'll heat it up for you and get it all packed for you to take to go. There's a playground a few blocks away (Argonne Playground), which is sadly the closest available public seating... but the pie is delicious if you eat it right after they've heated it up. The mashed potato crust is delicious and smooth, and the meat is spiced just right (not too strong).

Breakfast sandwiches: I had the Belfast Bap with my girlfriend one time, and it was the best breakfast sandwich I've ever, ever had. Bap is an amazing bread, chewy on the inside under a firm crust, and they packed sausages, bacon, eggs, and a light addition of cheese into an amazing sandwich. Served it to us heated, wrapped, and sliced. Perfect.

Go visit John Campbell's! It's worth the trip.
author: Charlie H.

description:
The jam cookies are buttery with a bit of fruit and sized right for a little nibble.  The Breakfast in bread, even toasted 2 days after I bought it, is phenomenal.

BUT a tad pricey, and cash only, which is a hassle.
author: Mia G.

description:
John Campbell's, a fine establishment in the Richmond district, provides it's customers with a wide variety of mouthwatering scones. The scones are roughly softball sized. I highly recommend the blueberry flavor for those who like something sweet but not overbearingly sugary. The bakery also offers different breads and other pastries. I recommend the Irish soda bread! 
Check this place out!
author: Deanna B.

description:
If you're craving a meal or snack in the Richmond and tired of the usual fare, give the Irish a try! When you walk in the storefront, expect to be surrounded by a plethora of foreign food. My savory faves for lunch or dinner include the foccacia sandwich, potato bacon mushroom brie, and veggie currie pastie. 

The sweets will satisfy any sweet tooth (as a sugarholic I consider myself an expert on such matters). My greatest sweet addiction here is the chocolate chip cream filled scone - a fresh baked chocolate chip full scone split in half, filled with fresh made whip cream and dabbed with raspberry jam (wowzers!). There's also plain and blueberry varieties. Snowballs are delicious and even more so heated up for 15-20 seconds in the microwave - instant coconut covered cakeballs! There's a variety of tarts to choose from (which you can mix 'n match 5 for $10) with my favorite being the almond raspberry tart.

The raspberry tea cookies are sweet, buttery; hard to eat just one but at 25 cents each at least its affordable to indulge. I have also found the combination of Barry's tea w/ cream and chocolate chip scones for breakfast a very satisfying breakfast combination. The cinnamon and sugar griddle cake is also nice for breakfast. It's similar in taste to a donut but not fried so healthier!

The store offers a wide range of breads. The pesto sun-dried tomato bread is fantastic but even better when you add hot pepper (or your choice) cheese toasted in the oven! The celtic almond bread is another fave loaded with almonds and full of marzipan. Finally, I recommend toasting chocolate-cherry bread in the oven and then adding a few scoops of vanilla ice cream (mmmm). 

Vegetarian Friendly Meals (NOT VEGAN)
-creamy tomato mushroom foccacia slice
-pesto artichoke foccacia slice
-vegetable currie pastie
-not officially vegetarian, but I pick the bacon off the potato mushroom brie and foccacia sandwiches (be prepared for some serious dissection work)

VEGAN breads
-Irish Crusty Bread
-Mini Irish Crusty Bread
-Belfast Bap Bread
These breads are all similar to French bread and good for sandwiches or with soup.
author: K H.

description:
A hidden gem in the midst of my neighborhood.  I have lived in the area for over ten years, have walked by this place countless times, and have never even batted an eyelash in that direction...... until today.

I got the shortbread which wasn't too sweet or greasy and deeeelish.  I also got a rhubarb pie (now I know what a rhubarb tastes like) and an egg custard pie -- both buttery goodnesses and not overly sweet.  I don't have much of a sweet tooth, and I actually wanted a savory pie...Five minutes later, I shoved a bunch of their sweet pies down my throat and didn't regret it at all.  I will definitely be back for more..................... mark. my. words.

I came in around dinner-time, but I am assuming a morning visit for fresh pastries would raise the stars to five.  On that note, to be continued.......................

P.S. They have a lot of vegetarian options too, so vegetarians: check it out!!!!
author: Betty W.

description:
Any place that has lots of samples is good in my book! This bakery is really small (and immaculate!) but has a lot to choose from. I can't speak to the authenticity of it's Irishness, but I did see quite a few imported items. 

The scones were light and fluffy unlike the little bricks I'm used to getting elsewhere & the fruit bun was good too. The little pecan tart was so tasty. It looked like pecan pie but had a totally different flavor. More savory than sweet. I sampled some cookies and they were delicious too. Overall, the flavors did not seem to be on the "too sweet" side like most baked goods. 

The prices were pretty reasonable. Most items are about $1-$1.50 each. Whatever I spent was worth it! 

The woman that was working was super friendly, I think she is the owner. Had she been grinding meat, I would have thought I was in a scene from So I Married an Axe Murderer :)
author: Kandace K.

description:
Thinking of an era filled with bangers and potato bread conjures up bittersweet memories of eating in Ireland with my mom, and being thirty pounds heavier because I just couldn't say no to it, regardless of how much I've eaten.

Driving through the hood, I was instructed to stop at the Irish Bakery for a quick to go lunch before rollin' over to my friend's house to chill for the day. I thank and curse him the same now for finding the place as I know that in the future, those extra pounds I'll need to work off my ass at the gym and in the studio are due to my fix needing to be filled. Upon walking into the petite bakery filled with people, as it was just after lunch, I was overwhelmed by the smell of fresh authentic Irish breads, pastries, and products I haven't seen since I was in Belfast, or even in Dublin. 

The soda bread was freshly baked that day, and fell apart in the bag as I consumed the large serving. His tart was delicious, and he ate it up like it was going out of style. The potato bread came in bags next to the lit up case, and samples (love my samples ya'll) abounded on the counter boasting garlic bread, delicious cookies, and the likes.....all authentic....

Now I have somewhere to go on Geary when I'm just feeling the need to expand my booty, and enjoy every bite of it while doing so.
author: Danielle S.

description:
My nose lead me to this inconspicuous bakery early this morning and boy, was I surprised to find so many baked goods.  It's heavenly on the eyes and nose.   

YES, it's heavenly on the taste buds too!  Their blueberry and chocolate chip scones are moist and fluffy, unlike the hard ones you find at most cafes.  Check it out folks!
author: Lisa L.

description:
After going to see the amazing Faberge eggs/Tiffany lamps exhibit at the Legion of Honor we passed by one of my favorite streets in SF, Geary. Geary is like a mini city with Russian video stores, Oriental produce markets, Thai lunch shops, German pubs and now one of my all-time favorites, John Campbell's Irish bakery.

What happened was that we were looking for a place to eat so we parked right in front of the bakery and started to feed the meter. Little did we know that a quarter could only cover 10 minutes - CRIMINAL.

So we had to look for change ... Luckily the people inside Campbell's were nice enough to give us 2 more dollars in quarters as a cover for an up and down the street walk. However, while inside, they had tastings of the most amazing double chocolate almond filled cakes. I tried some and was blown away, so chocolately, so flakey crusty, so sweet coconutty with a gracious blend of vanilla/almond filling. It stunned me and I almost fell back into the glass door with the rush of unexpected flavor flooding my mouth. I actually got dizzy and couldn't forget about it while I walked all over the place. It followed me everywhere.

So when I got back to the car, I just had to get a take-home sample for the way home to San Jose. What was the price for 5 little incredible pies... only TEN DOLLARS. Ten little insignificant dollars, 40 quarters, 1000 pennies to make a man happy beyond his wildest dreams. And no tax either. Yes, I dropped down 2 5's and that was it.

You have got to take advantage of this little store/bakery. Take your girl there, get her a blueberry scone or a delicious crumbly coffee cake that melts into your palm and on to the floor if you are not really, really careful. Get the rush for yourself that I got.

I am gushing I know but hey this place blew me away. An unexpected treasure that I am going to visit every time I return and I go to Geary A LOT.

What a find for me, I'm so happy.
author: Terry H.

description:
Scones were okay but tasted too much like biscuits.  I do have to say that their Bailey's scone was great.  Unfortunately, the scone itself has lots of baking soda and the flavor is inconsistent from day to day.  I had a sponge roll once.  It was extremely over priced and tasted like it had been baked right alongside a minced meat pie.  It was disgusting!

Went by in the early afternoon to pick up a scone only to realize that they don't make fresh scones throughout the day.  It's a bakery!!  I thought bakeries did more than one batch a day!  I can't vouch for freshness either.  Overall, it may be "genuine" but it definitely isn't fresh and not worth the price they want.  They raised the price recently to $1.75/scone.  Not worth it.

Oh yeah, the whole cash only thing, ANNOYING.
author: Angelica R.

description:
I had very high hopes for this place. I walked in on Sunday morning and the place was empty except for the two counter girls. Neither bothered to say hello. After standing there for an awkward minute, they asked if I needed any help. 

I ordered a beef pasty, a sausage roll, a mince pie, a rhubarb pie, an apricot tart, a raspberry tart, a custard tart and an almond raspberry tart. The real reaon I was there though was the Belfast Bap.

My fiance and I got home and had a tasting party while watching the original Clash of the Titans. 

The good: the beef pasty - absolutely perfect and deightful. Perfectly seasoned and the sublime crust. The sausage roll was very tasty and the rhubarb tart was bliss. Also, Clash of the Titans is just as awesome as ever.

The bad: the Belfast Bap was dry and badly needed seasoning. The same thing was true about the custard tart. The apricot and raspberry tart were too jammy. The almond raspberry was a bit too dry. The custard tart could be made better by adding some ofthe apricot filling. 

I am glad I tried such a big selection and I will definitely be back for the pasty and sausage roll. I will also bring cash so I can bring home some black and white pudding.
author: Jann J.

description: I'm a sucker for exceptional bakery..and this my fellow yelpers is truly one of them. Small business with great talent and wonderful product. Since seeing this a few months ago..i make it a point to go at least once a month. Their garlic bread and home made pizza style bread (pesto) are deelish!! It a cute small place but don't be fooled by cute, they also bake the best darn bread here!! This is my fav in the bay.
author: Ateh M.

description:
So happy to come across this wonderful bakery in our early morning jaunts.   Ike and I were happy to sample the raisin bread and other goodies John Campbell's has to offer.  

We went home with some yummy foccacia and irish soda bread.   Both very tasty.   

Hubby came back with us and we tried the mince and apple pies which were so so.  

We did get to try the open face sandwich, which i'm still thinking about... its been 2 weeks.   Will definitely go back there next Saturday!
author: Regi K.

description: Scones are so soft, tons of samples, breakfast bread is delish.
author: Matthew R.

description: Five stars for the soda bread with raisins; almost as good as my grandma made.  Cash only, friendly people behind the counter.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Wow, what an amazing bakery.  Freshly baked scones and breads and pastries of all descriptons.  John is an amazing baker.
author: Judith B.

description:
Oye! Being here took me back to days of backpacking and feeling like a starving idiot, rummaging through vending machines, sitting and waiting for a train when I should have known the schedules at Paddington Station. Paddington Station and their pastie booths. Many a nights I have fantasized about having a nice warm pastie but did not know where to pick one up. 

Look no further, this bakery has lots to choose from. Raisin scones, Irish bread, Plum Pudding, Mince Puffs(*squeals with delight*), Pasties, Mixed tartlets the list goes on and on. 

Squeeze yourself inside, grab a bag and pick up some scones or puffs and if you're like me, ask for a warmed veggie pastie. There are a few tinned items like mashed peas, beans and custard powder. If you're looking for Marmite and not Vegemite this is your place. A medium size jar is $6. Mmmm, this place could easily be a new weekly breakfast spot.
author: Morgan M.

description: Thought I drop by for once since I frequently walk by here. I bought some cookies and a foccacia slice, like a square shaped pizza. The cookies were decent and the foccacia wasn't too bad. I would like to come back since their menu is intriguing.
author: Mandy D.

description: What a diamond in the rough of a myriad sushi restaurants and coffee shops in the Outer Richmond.  The employees are friendly and helpful, they always have free samples, and the baked goods are oh so good.  There's never really a "need" to go in, but I always find some excuse.  As should you.
author: Jenn C.

description:
John Campbell's Irish Bakery proves that not only do the Irish know how to party and drink, but they sure can bake.

Buttery, light and orgasmic. Three words to describe the blueberry scones only at John Campbell's Irish Bakery. 

And it's super affordable at only $1.25 for a piece of heaven or $5.00 for 5 pieces of heaven.

This Irish bakery is so cute & pretty small - there are no chairs or tables, so it's just a quick grab-and-go kind of bakery. It's probably a good thing; otherwise, I'd be hogging all the blueberry scones and John Campbell would probably file a restraining order against me.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
Once again looking out for the latest sweet tooth shop to feed my addiction!

WOW! I came upon this place after dinner next to Kasa. I was always curious what was going to move into the place after the DVD Station closed. It was a sweet location and am glad to see an Irish Bakery move into it. Apparently John Campbell spent 30 years in Belfast perfecting these wonderful recipes and it will serve San Francisco well.

The first night we walked home after dinner with a blueberry scones an mini apple tart. The next week we walked out with 2 blueberry scones and some chocolate cherry bread. And today we picked up a blueberry scone as a gift for someone else so they can become addicted.

So far I'm very delighted...I had no idea my Irish heritage were so good at baking. I had two Irish grandmothers and of course a mother who could not come close to putting this on a table.

John Campbell's Irish Bakery offer many other delights and I especially  look forward to trying their shepherd's pie real soon.
author: Peter M.

description:
You can't beat the irish brown bread nor can you bead the breakfast Focaccia sandwich.
Help him out :) great guy
author: tim f.

description:
TIME TRAVEL ON THE CHEAP.
How many times in your life have you had the opportunity to tactilely re-experience a wonderful memory by smelling or tasting something familiar? And if you've been lucky enough to be transported back in time by something as innocent as a smell or taste would you want to share that pleasure with others? If you answered yes and are looking for just such an experience there is a little store front bakery in San Francisco's Richmond District that will take you back in time when you walk through the front door.

If you've ever wondered where to buy Irish scones (real Irish scones) or Irish brown bread (real Irish brown bread) there is a place outside of Ireland, next to a bar called The Blarney Stone on Geary Blvd. It is an Irish bakery started two years ago by a product of Belfast's legendary apprentice system. Master Baker John Campbell holds an Order of The Master Baker from Belfast City and a Guilds Bakery Certificate. 

What this means to you and me is an honest to God trained journeyman Irish baker who specializes in aromatic flavorful time machines of authentic Irish baked goods that will send you to the stony fields of Eire for as little as a $1 per scone or $5 for a loaf of brown bread, (which must be experienced warm with a slather of crunchy peanut butter to truly understand what it means to live in a smoky thatched roofed cottage ringed by dry stone walls built eons ago by hands unseen). A modest well made scone or slice of warm brown bread can be a powerful thing.  

Scoff you may, guffaw you might, but having lived in Ireland for eight years as a teenager I feel qualified to vouch for just how real and authentic the baked goods are that Mr. Campbell is producing locally. The storefront is also authentically Irish with its style of font and window display. And if you really want to know how good Johns scones are try muscling your way through the throngs of elderly Chinese ladies that habituate the bakery as if they owned the place. That's how good this bakery is; you have to fight your way past people of other nationalities to get to your own.

Of special note are the raisin scones, soda and brown breads, sausage rolls with either pork or beef sausage filling and the raspberry chocolate bread. Oh my God the raspberry chocolate bread... and yes it tastes as good as it sounds. John also makes Guinness bread, traditional pasties, soups and rhubarb crumble. Walking into Campbell's Irish Bakery is walking into the middle of a time in your life you most likely have forgotten or maybe never had; that time when a sensation of smell and taste turned you into a humble believer in things greater than yourself.  

One way or another sampling John's baked goods will reignite pleasant memories and transport you to a place far far away from your current state of mind for a fraction of the cost of a vacation. Pamper yourself this spring and take a trip to a mountainside that slopes into a sheltered bay where little white cottages pepper the landscape as they have for centuries. Experience the aromas and flavors of food that has been perfected over the centuries and is a product of a country that has populated the United States with people, music and food, great food. John Campbell's Irish Bakery.
author: Todd B.

description:
5 scones for $5!

They are fluffy, moist, and tasty with afternoon tea.

They have pasties which I hate to mention because I would rather you buy pie from me. But it all looked good.
author: Esa Y.

description:
The baker that made the oatmeal chocolate chip cookies is gone and so is the recipe.

ALSO: they're changing the sweet potato bran muffin recipe due to it being too "gooey". You won't see if for at least a few weeks. This makes me very nervous as that is my favorite item there. I won't change my rating yet but John Campbell, you are on notice.
author: Cherry P.

description:
Scones, mushroom shepherds pie and vegetable curry pastie are big winners. 

The only reason I knock off a star is that the service is friendly, but slow, and they keep giving me the wrong thing, so I end up pulling meat out of my pastie when I had ordered the vegetarian option. Otherwise, I like dropping in while waiting for the bus and picking something up for the day.
author: V K.

description:
Amazing food.  I cannot stress that enough.  I've tried tarts, stuffed...things?  I could go on and on.  If you are reading reviews and thinking about trying this place, let me assure you that you will be delighted.

The folks who work here are also very friendly and are great help when you can't decide which piece of heaven you want to enjoy.
author: alex l.

description:
This place has gone down hill in the last month or so. Two of the last three occasions that I've gone here, when I returned home I realized they had given me day-old stuff. Their prices are pretty high to begin with, at least they should give you fresh stuff. 

I had a pasty that was definitely two to three days old and some foccacia that was like a rock. The scones were good and fresh though.
author: Hank S.

description:
I'm still eating the blueberry scones and I'm still in love with them. 

I want to give a shout out to the tall, red-headed dude who works behind the counter. He's pretty much awesome. He always has some fun comment whenever I come in, he gave me a free sample of the coconut raspberry ball (which could be one of the best balls to ever cross my mouth), and he's always in a good mood. 

Great customer service from him and many others who work here. 

I'm now starting a fan club called "Cool Red Heads who work in the Richmond" and he is the first member.
author: Jared S.

description:
I love this bakery.  Everything is made from scratch and although the main chef/cook seems less friendly than his employees, they are awesome.  So friendly and so helpful and just sweet.

My favorites are the curry chicken pasties and the apple crumb mini tarts and the vegetable focaccia pizza thing.  Oh my goodness just thinking about them is making me hungry.  Ooo!  The soups are really good too!

I took my friend there and she got a cup of hot coffee and the meat focaccia pizza thing for 5 bucks and she was super thrilled by it.  They will heat any item if you desire.  Ooo!  The scones, oh those yummy, fluffy, scones...
author: Susan C.

description: I was very very impressed with this place when my friend and I walked in.  The gentleman in the counter was very friendly and greeted us as we could smell the wonderful aromas of the Sheppard's pies.  We ordered a Sheppard's pie and a curry one and ordered 5 tarts and a sausage roll.  The guy was so nice to us he threw in a free tart and gave us the sausage roll for free.  When we ate it back home it tasted so good!  The flavors were to my liking and adding sriracha made it even better!  I definitely was satisfied and I will be visiting weekly now. LOL =D
author: John H.

description:
I've worked here since they first opened in May 2007. Talk about never being able to go on a diet.  I thought after a while I would get tired of the food there, but no, unfortunately I haven't.  I would volunteer the morning shift just so I could have my chocolate chip scone straight form out of the oven,and it was definitely worth getting up at 5:30am, even on the weekends.  
     This place not only contains MOUTH WATERING baked goods, desserts, and savory items, but it also has a wonderful staff, with the odd exceptions here and there.  This has become a family to me, and I love coming to visit when I'm away at school during the school semester.  John is a wonderful boss, friend, and person, and someone I really enjoy working for.  All the staff in the back are great and so are they in the front!  A great deal of time and effort goes into this place, and when you come inside you can definitely see that.  The quality of the products are wonderful,and I would know since I work there.

So come on by and enjoy our wonderful products and our friendly staff!!!
author: Liliya D.

description:
Yesterday my girlfriend and I wandered in to this incredible establishment and left with a new sense of Irish heritage pride. I mean, us Irish possess many great abilities in life (ability to consume massive amounts of alcohol, inventive cursing techniques etc.) but one thing we definitely aren't known for is our food. Apart from our corned beef and stew (both which have contributed to my poor health) we don't have much to brag about... until now.

As of now I can only speak for their baked goods (by the way, FREE SAMPLES), the most amazing breads I have tasted in a long time. We bought a Pecorino garlic bread of some sort that was doughy, crusty, cheesy and contained full cloves of  carmelized garlic. INSANE.

I avoid the Marina like I avoid the proctologist, but I will definitely be trekking back for some more bread!
author: devon m.

description:
If you have not made the trip to the famous Irish Bakery, put it on your "things to do before I die list". Under that put eat a Belfast Bap, soda bread, pastie, and 5 scones. Do that in one sitting, good luck finishing the rest of your list. 

The bakery is conveniently located next to the Blarney Stone. As in oh how convenient I can have a beer too! Small shop. The scones are in the glass display case to your left immediately upon entering. Help yourself to a brown bag. Scones are a deal at $5 for 5, and you can mix and match. All of them are light and pack in the taste. Get 2 Bailey's Irish cream, one chocolate and two blueberry. 

Next comes one of the best breakfast sandwiches you will experience. The Belfast Bap is large and delicious. Giant round of bread filled with cheese, egg, sausage and bacon. Heart clogging heaven.
author: Ryan G.

description:
I can't believe I never knew this place existed!! I've been living in this area FOREVER and had no idea!! My sister raved to me about this bakery and I finally checked it out!!

I came here twice already. The first visit was for their scones... I had the blueberry scone and it was just like every yelp... It was moist, flaky and delicious. It's has more of a biscuit texture. On my second visit, I tried their breakfast sandwiches. They are pre-made, but once heated, it's like fresh! I had the Belfast bap, which was a breakfast sandwich made from fresh bap bread with Irish sausage, bacon, scrambled eggs and cheddar cheese. This thing is HUGE! I only ate half of it, but the bread was so good... crispy and soft... It was sandwiched with two whole sausages and a thin slice of bacon. It was yummy. My bf had the other foccacia sandwich, but it wasn't as good as mine. His sandwich was made with only bacon, cheese and a "poached" egg on foccaica bread. 

I also love that they have free samples! I tried the Guinness bread, pesto & tomato and garlic bread... all yummy!!

You must try John Campbell's!!!
author: Denise L.

description: Prices increased, but it's still good. They don't serve the mushroom-parsnip shephard's pie anymore (only in soup form) but the original beef and peas is still yummy. . the scones are still the best i have had. Irish Breakfast Tea is a rip off for $2.00 for bag tea and hot water. Everyone kept getting the Belfast Bap (best value), must try next time.  The lady with the fiery red hair and fishnet stockings was nice and attentive.
author: William H.

description:
This place is such a hidden gem on Geary Street. 

Their pasties are delicious and perfect for those fog filled, cold San Francisco days when you want comforting, stick to your ribs food.   Although all of them are very tasty, the chicken and curry packs a nice amount of heat.  You can have them heat one up for you so you can walk down Geary and take in the sites or take some home to heat up later. 

Also, the "Club" soda is so refreshing.  Get the "Rock Shandy", which is a mix of lemon and orange.  

All of their pastries are DELICIOUS and the breads are outta this world.

***WARNING***THIS PLACE IS CASH ONLY***
author: Kim S.

description: One of my favorite dishes is Shepherd's Pie and theirs is very good. My sister thought it was too salty, but I loved it. I've only been here a few times. I've always come by for their potato bread, but they sold out one day so I got a brie, bacon and mushroom potato bread thingy. Hmm Hmm, yummy goodness. Friendly staff, free samples and delicious savory and sweet food. Can't beat that. I'll be back for more!
author: Lotus L.

description: On a whim with a few extra minutes I decided I wanted a cookie from the Irish Bakery near my appointment.  I didn't quite see the cookies until after I had made my purchase.  I chose a little almond and rasberry jam tart.  I just ate it.  It was beyond perfect.  Perfect crust, perfect almond paste or marzipan, perfect amount of jam, no spillage.  A perfect 5 or six bites.  I was satisfied and of course wanted more.  Tomorrow I will try the John Capbell's near
author: Carey C.

description:
Can't believe how good the Guinness bread is. It's got cranberries and walnuts and has really great flavor. You can taste a hint of the Guinness in it. I was also impressed by the mince tarts.... delicious! I love mince pies and it's hard to find really good ones. These were indeed good.

The guy behind the counter was very knowledgeable and built up a rapport with the wife and even gave her some freebies to try. 

Definitely one of the businesses which know how to keep customers happy!
author: Maury M.

description:
Mince Pie -- #1 MINCE PIE in San Francisco!!

Actually, this is the only place in San Francisco that I know selling Mince Pie.  The Mince Pie is a small pie 3" in diameter that has a compote center of currants, raisins, cherries and apricots spiced with nutmeg and cinnamon.  It is dusted on the top with sugar. The pie is usually eaten as a Christmas tradition in the UK, but John Campbells Irish Bakery serves it year round.  Bless this bakery!

I have tried to convince my husband that the mince pie should be eaten around Christmas time.  But he will have none of it -- he bought 8 mince pies last weekend. This is June!  I remember around the holidays last year that the mince pie was very popular.  The bakery didn't bother putting it in the glass case, as there were multiple trays on the back counter.  So long as there's a demand, they will make them.

The bakery also serves great breads and pastries.  All items are baked in the Irish tradition.  Favorites include Irish soda bread and chicken pastie.  I made a recent discovery and tried the cream filled scone, one with powdered sugar and the other with almonds and powdered sugar.  It reminded me of a cream puff -- very good.

It should be known that the owners of the bakery and the Irish bar next door are friends.  Adds to the quaintness of the place.  Give this bakery a try!
author: Janet H.

description: God is Irish and his name is John Cambell. Words alone would not do them justice.
author: Honest T.

description:
Everytime I'm there, I go for the scones.  They're the absolute best!
If you had Starbucks or Peet's scones, then you had this place.  There's no comparison.  Nice and light.  They sell out of the chocolate raspberry ones quick, but the other are dam good too!  I need to start trying the other stuff.
author: Peter L.

description:
There isn't one thing I haven't tried and not LOVED at John Campbell's Irish Bakery!  My all-time favorites are the chocolate chip scones or any of the scones for that matter.  I love that they are moist and not super sweet.  Even a day or so later they still hold up fine.  The soda bread and custard tarts are also excellent.  Coffee there is nice too.  

I often am scrambling around for breakfast, but at least once a week I know I'll stop by the bakery for a scone...super convenient that it's on my way to the bus stop, but I'd go out of my way if it wasn't....they're that good!
author: Marie B.

description: I love this bakery very much!! It has a wide variety of bread types! Very delicious & good price! :)
author: Palmy L.

description:
I am so getting laid tonight!

I picked up home-style Irish goodies for the husband, who hasn't been back to Ireland in over a year, and is desperately missing home. 

I also indulged in a sausage roll, and was nearly inspired enough to write an ode to it, but I only got as far as "left a greasy smudge on my fingertips" before I lost interest. That, and I'd already moved on to the DELIGHTFUL brown bread. (side note: if you're ever feeling sick, having soldiers made with brown bread to dip in your your soft-boiled eggs...heaven!) 

The also carry a small variety of hard-to-find sodas - namely Club Shandy and Club Lemons, which make brilliant mixers for gin. 

I will be back. Oh yes. Frequently. 

Thank you John Campbell, for your wonderful wonderful bakery.
author: teriaki b.

description:
Having never been to Ireland, but having tasted English made Irish fare I have some idea, but am sure may offend some irish folks. 

The Potato bread was AWESOME!
The shepards Pie was between OK and AWESOME!
The scones: Blueberry- Oh soo good
Chocolate chip- YES!
Choco-cran - eh...not my flavor but good
Bailey's - amazing!


Focccia - Pretty Good and Fattening

The bread consistancy was in alomst perfect, firm crust, giving way to soft moist innards.  I like the small batch preparation they do that really reigns in that homemade feel. 


I walked in after eating lunch and still left with way too much. Also cash only so come prepared!  

An excellent little spot in the richmond for your Irish pastry fix!
author: Spanky M.

description:
Being a undercover pastry lover, I've eaten my fair share of scones across the US and beyond.  The delights served here are different from the typical American scone, softball-sized pastries which are moist and dense on the inside with craggy, crumbly, crunchy exteriors, the product of generous amounts of butter and cream.  American scones = diet killers.

In contrast, John Campbell's scones are pillowy soft, with just enough sweetness and interest to distinguish it from a being a mere biscuit.  I wasn't particularly enamoured of the raspberry chocolate, but I devoured the blueberry with gusto.  The chocolate chip was also very nice, with a pleasant dough to chocolate ratio.  Chocolate chip scones have a way of disappointing me because I invariably compare them to chocolate chip cookies, but I couldn't have been more pleasantly surprised.  I bought a half dozen because I couldn't resist purchasing 6 for $6, so the raisin and irish liquor scones are waiting to be devoured.

The only thing that didn't agree with me was the hot cross bun.  A little too heavy on the clove for my tastes, but I did enjoy the samples of pecan tart and brown bread that were put out for customers to taste.

This is now my go-to place for scones!
author: Janet L.

description:
First impression: Wow..!

I was waiting for the bus this morning, and I got hungry. I was too lazy to cross the street to the coffee shop (thank God I didn't go there.. that place got bad reviews..) so I walked 5 steps to the left and saw the word "bakery." I wasn't expecting much because the store was really tiny, the lights were dimly lit, and there were only two people behind the counter.. 

A lot of the pastries were self-served. Like, you take a paper bag and pick the piece you want from their shelves. It reminded me of the bakery back in UCDavis.. =X  But omfg, the quality of the goods do not compare at all. The scones here are delicious! They really do not feel oily / buttery like the other scones I've had. And the taste is effing amazing! Great taste and I'm not clogging my arteries. What more could I ask for? 

I will definitely come back here to try their other offerings. The shepherd's pie looked yum :3
author: Audris K.

description:
Pasties were unbelievable ! Sausage Rolls- AMAZING ! And the scones and apple turnovers were great. Love love love this place ! Can't wait to go back. 
Service was great - very nice ( and the guy was a cutie too ) !! :o)
author: Melissa K.

description:
Number One Son's daddy is a Paddy and so I know of what I speak.  This place rocks!  

Not only is John Campbell a swell guy, but he's an awesome baker.  After doing his thing out of the Blarney Stone (Paddy daddy's local) for a while (and do try their weekend breakies and brunch, bring the kids, too), he's got his own shop now where one can get all manner of deliciousness.  Try the brown bread (it's delicious and light and lovely and made I think from angel wings and imported flour) and the soda bread, and the cream buns (I would sell my soul for the cream buns) and the sausage rolls... and the fadge (potato bread for those west of the Island).  Number One Son highly recommends the baps-- his favorite is the Belfast bap (which is only right, as Paddy Daddy is from there;  "we don't say 'from the North,' cos there is only one Ireland"-- Paddy Daddy).  If you are lucky enough to get eels from Lough Neagh posted to you, the brown bread will be the fitting side.  

There is really too much goodness here to detail all:  sheppard's pie, tarts, shortbread and more.  Just like homemade, but even better.  (Don't tell Paddy Daddy's sisters I said that).
author: Nicola F.

description:
What's not to love about John Campbell's Irish Bakery? They have the most delicious treats.  Be sure to try the rhubarb, apple, custard, etc. tarts, they are small enough to not feel guilty if you try two (who am I kidding - three!) The snowballs are amazing and be sure to try the flaky apple dessert.  I forget what it's called, but it is amazing.

For lunch or dinner try the Shepards Pie (mashed potatoes, beef and peas) which is fantatstic or any of their sandwiches

For those of you that enjoy authentic Irish food, like Irish bacon (oh my god, you have NOT lived until you try it) or Irish pudding - either black or regular), they carry a varity of meats, butter and treats

One last point.  The staff is always helpful, friendly and very sweet.  This has quickly become my favorite place for breakfast, lunch or dinner.  Just one drawback - they only take cash, so make sure you come prepared. :).
author: Jennifer U.

description: Awesome!!!  One of my all time favorite places for a bite to eat.  Try the Chicken Curry Shepherd's Pie, and the Apple Puff for a stellar meal.  There 25 cent shortbread cookies melt in your mouth.  They have a wide variety of sweet and savory, and the staff is kind and attentive.  They will heat up your food for you if you want.
author: Charm D.

description:
This bakery is small, family owned and really puts off a great vibe.  The Irish brown bread is flavorful, hearty and delicious.  I drive 30 something blocks just to get it.  Also, their scones are great...even the plain ones.  Also, my dad loves all of their savory pastries.  Minus one star for only being open until 3 on Sundays, and for being out of the brown bread.  What can I say?  That bread is popular.

**********UPDATE***********

I went in today (the same day as my original review), and I had such a good experience that I am upgrading to 5 stars for 3 reasons. 1.  They had an abundant supply of brown bread at 4:30 in the afternoon  2.  One of the owners, Brian, came out behind the back to introduce himself and made my coffee himself AND invited me in the back to see how they make their coffee. Now THATS customer service. 3.  This coffee is STRONG, just how I like it.  I'm never getting coffee at the starbucks a few blocks away again!
author: Genevieve M.

description: For a brief, wonderful moment, we had John Campbell on Potrero Hill. Alas, the neighborhood did not support this wonderful bakery, and it closed. I drive across the City to procure their wonderful brown Bread, and it's worth having to stop at every red light on Geary.
author: Kathy P.

description:
I love this place!  Whenever I walk by, I lose my calorie-counting self-control and wander inside, ooh'ing and ahh'ing over the various Irish baked goods.  The people are patient and nice here as I take my sweet time deciding.

I love the scones because they're unlike scones you get at normal coffee shops.  They are light and fluffy and melt in your mouth.  They don't fall apart into a crumbly mess (like normal scones).  I would almost compare them to biscuit - a much lighter version of one.

I've had their mince tart, their almond chocolate tart, Shepherd's pie (SO MUCH YUM!), chicken curry pastie, and Belfast Bap.  All very, very good!  And decent prices, too!

Definitely get the sandwiches heated up.  And go for a 4 mile run afterward.
author: L Y.

description:
I have only one word.
THE BEST BLUEBERRY SCONES ANYWHERE EVER!

I come up from Palo Alto just for the scones... I always try other things and have enjoyed everything I have tried. (special mention of the White SnowBalls - yumm)

But the blueberry scones - oh dear lord they are worth the drive.....
author: Jimmy G.

description: All the pasties are great, you can have a great casual lunch as they will heat your food and deliver it to the Blarney Stone pub next door. I think they are cash only.
author: Scott A.

description:
I've been going here lately because Arizmendi is closed for the holidays.  I like this place considerably, actually, and it's much closer to my house than Arizmendi, but it's the 2nd best bakery in SF in my mind.

The best thing they have is "Stout" Coffee, which seriously is the closest that coffee can ever get to beer without the two actually being in the same cup (would that be good?)

The hearty foods are much better than the sweets, in my opinion.  Go for the Shepard's Pie or Belfast Bap, but make sure you're planning to workout afterward.  I tried the Potato bread, but I was pretty let down and I think it's over-rated.  I probably would've enjoyed it a lot more if I hadn't read the yelp reviews first.
author: Jin D.

description: I stumbled upon this lovely place today while walking down Geary. The Tayto sign got my attention, and I stopped in to see if they sold Barry's Irish tea. Indeed, they had a big box of it for $16, and I resisted buying it today (I'm trying to save money) and assured the girl at the counter I would come back.
