"Would you like a cup?" she asked, and I bought one. She even gave me a few teabags for free! Great service; I'm definitely coming back, and I can't wait to try the raisin soda bread!
author: Leigh H.

description: Almost forgot to review this. Gf & I stopped in a couple weeks ago. Had an excellent curried vegetable pastie and a pretty good chocolate "haystack" (kind of like a coconut bar, for those of you who remember those). So many temptations, so few stomachs (unless you're a ruminant or whale).
author: J R.

description: While waiting for the Geary bus, I stumbled on this awesome bakery.  I tried the brown bread, curry puffs and this small chocolate tart with almonds.  Everything was amazing.  Gotta admit I am a fool for tat almond tart.  The only drag I I live in SOMA and this is the putter Richmond.  Thankful for the 38L!  This place is worth the trip.
author: Tim M.

description:
Friendly service.  Good prices.

I came here for dessert after downing a huge bowl of pho over on Clement.

$1.50 for a delicious, perfectly baked raisin scone.  They have other flavors too, including blueberry and Bailey's Irish Creme.  I checked all the baskets and there seemed to be a run on the plain and raisin scones that morning.  Must be popular.

I am a pro-carbohydrate French-baguette-devouring bread, pastry, and scone snob, and I love this place.

I'm going to get a bunch of plain scones next time, take them home or to the beach, and smother them with some of my favorite French butter from Celles sur Belle.

Scone heaven! :)
author: Justin C.

description:
Cheers to you, Mr. John Campbell, for opening up such an institution of finely baked goods baked with the goodness that is expected from a fine bakery. Your scones, to die for. I call them Irish scones. They're different from other scones. Just not sure how but they just taste different and better than most other scones I have ever tried. Beautifully crafted shepherd's pie with a smooth meaty gravy. Better than the blasphemes version at the Cheesecake Factory. 

And of course, your lasses that you have working behind the counter. They be the main attraction of the store to lads like me and those that frequent the adjacent pub. I'm not saying the food isn't a draw but the lasses are definitely easy on the eyes. I thank you dearly, sir.
author: Anthony L.

description:
I never liked scones because of their dry, dense texture.  Then I had some scones made by Sconehenge, and I found out what good scones taste like.

Well I came to John Campbell's and now I know what the BEST scones taste like.  Absolutely fantastic.

The girls there drive me crazy.  Just say anything and you make me melt.
author: Josh L.

description: This place is a great find! Delicious and fresh baked goods. Awesome scones, not too sweet, melt in your mouth. Bread is soft and so good.
author: tureg u.

description: One word: inconsistent and one of the staff conducts business in a shady way. I always loved this place until recent months. I usually get morning coffee and misc bites there. I like the feel of the place and usually the staff is friendly and is a great way to start the day. But recently, one of the newer face there just makes ridiculous and illogical demands. Only her too. One time, they ran out of the big cup for coffee and only had the small cups. So I got a small coffee but she insisted that cup was the large size and I should pay the large amount. The cup is obviously the small. I get coffee there every morning. Difference is hmmm obvious. I disagreed and after some awkward moments, she relented. Then this morning, they only had the small cup again. When I went to pay the small, she said it is two dollars (price of the large) and I thought maybe they raised their prices. So I paid. On my way out I asked her are they not going to have two sizes anymore? She said no. They just ran out of the other cups.  What????? So you raised my small cup of coffee by more than 30 percent because you didn't buy big cups to offer that day?  I didn't get more coffee that day. Why should I pay more? John Campbell. Listen to your customer, correct this business behavior that crooks use. I told her there is no logic to this and I left. Quite frankly, it's 50 cent. Who cares! but you just lost a customer.
author: P L.

description: Friendly person was working there, he gave me FREE cookies!!! Isn't that sweet or what! loved the bakery, loved every thing there. fresh and delicious is the right word for this humble place! I would encourage every one to go there!!!!
author: S F.

description:
Wow! This place is awesome.

The shepherd's pie is to die for. It might be a tad too salty for some but it's perfect for someone who loves heavily-spiced food like me. I hate minced meat as they usually are too dry but it's moist and flavorful here.

The chicken curry pie is as good, if not better, than the shepherd's pie. Again, I hate white-meat chicken but it's tender and not dry here. It's also well-spiced, like the first one.
author: Handoyo S.

description:
I love this place.  It is the only real Irish bakery in San Francisco, and according to the people working there, in the Bay Area.  Apparently Irish people come over from San Mateo, etc. all the time.

Coffee was good and I am in love with the ordinary raisin scones - light and fluffy, like a biscuit.....They are a cute little business, only open for 7 months now, so if you like Irish people, Irish food, or baked goods, you should think about supporting them.
author: Heather H.

description:
The scone deal--5 scones for $5--is great, and the variety of baked goods is fun.  I bought scones, Guinness bread, potato bread and my boyfriend bought a Belfast Bap (sausage/bacon/egg/cheese sandwich).  Altogether we spent around $15, so it was relatively cheap.

Unfortunately, nothing we got was very moving.  The scones were decent, though much different than an average scone.  If anything, they were a bit plain.  The potato bread, again, was on the plain side, though it did have a good, dense texture.  The Guinness bread was, in my opinion, the best of the lot--with cranberries popping with flavor and some nuts (walnuts, I think, if I remember correctly), in addition to a slightly Guinness-y flavor.

Overall, John Campbell's Irish Bakery was good, in a simple and sort of plain way.  However, it was not moving, and I wouldn't travel all the way to the Richmond for it again.  I would stop in again if I was in the area for other reasons though.
author: Jessica H.

description: OMG the breakfast baps! Dang!  they are 'get the paddles cuz this is worth a coronary' good.  Try one of each with a friend or 3 - they are huge!  Fried egg, Irish bacon, cheese on onion bread or scrambled eggs, cheese, Irish bacon and sausage on a big fresh bap (roll).  Sluurp!  The scones are quite good but very different from American scones (more biscuit like).  Will try other items like the pasties and cream buns once i've worked off the sinful baps. (fyi it's pronounced pah-sty not pay-sty)
author: Julienne G.

description: YUM. The griddle cakes are fantastic, and the filled cookies rolled in sugar looked awesome.
author: Alex L.

description:
John Campbell's is a hidden treasure in the Outer Richmond area. The first thing that caught my eye when I entered was a little fridge full of Lilt, one of my favorite soft driks from the UK. Took me a while to decide what I wanted, as everything on display looked tantalizing. Made my mind up for a pork pie and plain bap. Both were delicious and uber filling. Even got a little brown sauce to go. There were quite a few free samples to choose from while I waited for the pork pie to be heated upl.
Only minuses for this place are the prices, which are quite high and the limited selection of items (for example there is only one flavor of crisps - it's cheese & onion but nevertheless) but given the size of the bakery these are to be expected. Had the preconceived notion that it would be full of Irish but instead ran into friendly Americans working there.
author: Wilson S.

description: The chocolate chip cream filled scones are my favorite. The breakfast sandwiches are the bomb. Really hearty and filling. Good prices, good service, good variety. I love it!
author: Michelle W.

description:
Oh, oh, oh the buttery melt in your mouth scones!  They were so good I took 20 of them with me to share the goodness.

This place is a gem. I took my FH here to test the authenticity. He is from Belfast and the baker is from Belfast so I thought it would be interesting to see whether it was infact a taste of the real deal. He had the Sausage Roll and I had the Chicken Curry Pastie.  My chicken curry pastie was scrumptious and had the right amount of spices, the pastry was light, flakey, and buttery.  YUM!!!  Although, the Sausage Roll didn't win any points with my FH.   He said the roll was made out of minced meat when it should be a SAUSAGE!  Hence, SAUSAGE ROLL! He said it wasn't terrible but not great.  I thought it was good, but what do I know? I didn't grow up eating this stuff.

And he thinks that he's not a food snob!  Yeah, right!
author: Madlyne P.

description:
When I walk into a bakery, I immediately look for two things, before I even start to ogle the goods: if there are day-old goods, and if there are free samples. John Campbell's has the latter, and not the former (note to bakeries: you should all have day old selections! If I was just too late to see them, someone let me know). 
Anyway, thanks to the free samples, I found out their brown bread is great - quite substantial and hearty. There was another type of bread (I have unfortunately forgotten the name, which is something unusual that I hadn't heard of before - farl?) that was just about the opposite, but also very good - very light and fluffy, and would probably be quite pleasant with jam. The chocolate chip cookies were too buttery for my liking (although they were good - just not my type). There were a couple more things out, so, great selection of samples.
Don't worry, I did actually purchase something - scones and tea cookies. In general I think I'm not crazy about their cookies, but the scones were pretty nice and not too sweet. They're a good size - not monstrous, but big enough. Also, all of the pricing here seemed reasonable, which is always surprising for a bakery in the city. The staff were very friendly and helpful.
author: Lisa K.

description: Time to get my scone fixed on Easter Sunday here. I got 3 Blueberry scones and my favorite Beef Pasties. I got to the counter and the gentleman said if I got 3 more scone (total of 6), it would be only $7.00 bucks instead of $1.75 per for the scones!! Geezz, hell YES, got my 6 scone and a Beef Pastie. There is a Easter Bunny after all.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
Pick up a chicken veggie pasty, some Guiness from next door and some Arrested Development and you got yourself a fantastic Friday afternoon.  The pasty's so full that with the filling that falls out, you can add a little broth and baby, you got yourself a stew!  But if you don't want to go all Carl Weathers, they also started carrying soup-big fan of the chicken curry, but the green pea was mean too.  

Look out for extended hours on Saturday-soon to be staying open till 11pm, that's gonna be some great drunk food.

Update: they are now a cash only business.
author: Mike U.

description:
Imagine my surprise and visualize my double take as I passed by this bakery the other day. The scones were calling out to me, and I was not alone.
I went in and the helpful man behind the counter immediately packaged a couple of scones for me. I took them home and had them with a huge mug of PG Tips tea.

It looks like you can get all sorts of Irish treats here, and they serve coffee and Barry's tea as well!
author: Rachel M.

description: Simply try it, all of it.  Get something to munch on first, then a meal later, and then some munchies for a pic nic the next day.  This place has great food, Soda Bread is pleasant, but get there in the early afternoon if you want to try any of the really good stuff.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Outstanding, just outstanding. A rare five stars from me. Step in the door and you are no longer in SF. Everyone has a lovely Irish accent, both customers and staff. 

The coffee is good, but get the Barry's tea. That tea with one of the wonderful little tarts, especially the apple with the fantastic whipped cream is one of the best things in the Bay Area. 

What is nice is they have about a dozen samples on top of the counter.

Beef and vegetable pasty: Indescribably great. A light flakey crust filled with savory delicous coarsely chopped beef with some potatoes, peas and carrots, but mostly beef. It is a little salty but still delicious. 

Irish crusty bread: A sample today and there is no other bread in SF as wonderful as this. Soft with a light crust. 

Scones: Similar to Sconehenge scones but lighter and more elegant. I picked up a chocolate chip scone instead of currant. It was still very good. The plain has a little more baking soda in it but not too much. It is delicious with jam. 

Shortbread, Small thin round cookies that are delicate and buttery as shortbread should be. 

Custard tarts: One of the best I've every had with a delicate buttery crust and a light as air custard.
author: Rworange X.

description:
We got the blueberry scones. Sure. They are pretty delicious, but this review is all about the Mince Meat! Mince puffs, mince tarts...just like grandma used to make. Warning: mince meat is an acquired taste, so don't run out and get them if you are unadventurous. But do run out and get them if you have fond memories of Thanksgiving with the Sullies back Boston way.

(oh and nice, friendly service and good prices and all that.)
author: Melinda B.

description:
I love this bakery! Not only are their baked goodies super yummy, but the staff is also very nice and friendly and they always have samples out. Their chocolate chip scone is really light, buttery and flaky, and they have this cherry chocolate bread that is super good!
I'm in love with their Irish brown bread and so is my family in San Diego, i bring them a loaf every time I head down there. They have a good variety of various baked goods, both sweet and savory, and there's an Irish pub next door where you can take any sandwiches you order to go. Oh, and around Easter time they make some damn good hot cross buns. Definitely worth a visit!
author: Roxanne C.

description:
BEST coffee..strong and rich.. just how I like it.  They make it custom to how you like it!
BEST scones!  Not the bland lump of dough kind but like a buttery biscuit!  My favorite is the raisin scone but they have blueberry, plain and chocolate chip. $5 for 5 mix and match.
author: SFFoodie F.

description:
This place is incredible. The Belfast Bap is a revelation that must be experienced. The scones are a great price and delicious. I haven't had pasties this good outside the UK. Oh, and the coffee is amazing. Did I mention that you can use the patio at the attached pub to eat your food outside on a rare sunny day in the Richmond?

I go here whenever I can, which is often.
author: J G.

description:
After reading so much about this bakery, I had really high expectations for their scones.  I finally went after work today and got half a dozen scones (2 chocolate chip raspberries and 4 blueberries) for $6, which is an awesome deal.  Don't get me wrong, their scones aren't bad either...they just weren't great.  IMHO, they tasted more like a biscuit with blueberries than a scone.  When I think scones, I think nice crust with moist, sort of cake-like center.  Instead, the texture of their scone was like I had said...like that of a biscuit.  Maybe that's what Irish scones are supposed to be like *shrug*

On a different note, the lady working there was really nice and friendly.  Everything also smelled really yummy there so I'll probably come again and try something else.  Perhaps, I'll even give those scones another try.
author: Katelynn L.

description: It is nice to find a unique Irish bakery in San Francisco. The place is small, cozy, and has food you probably have never heard of. The prices are decent too. Some are $2.50 and some go up to $8. Either way the place wasn't bad. I forgot which one I got, but I remember the mushrooms on it tasting very good. My girlfriend also got something with pesto sauce and it wasn't bad too. Just know that some have Parmesan cheese on them so expect to have stanky breath afterward.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
***It's magically delicious.***

(Insert groan here)

Sorry. I couldn't help myself. 

Moving along: I noticed this place last week during my morning drive to work down Geary. Now, I miss few things in this world as much as the brown bread and butter that's ubiquitous in Ireland, so I made a mental note to pop in and check it out. This morning I went by and oh. my. God. While I was waiting for my sausage roll to be heated and my chicken & veg pasty to be bagged, I sampled some of the soda bread, and it took me right back to Ireland........seriously. It was SO good. I didn't even realize how much I missed it! 

I grabbed a menu as I went out and I can see I'm going to spend my time working my way through it........batch bread, pasties, shepherd's pie, oh my! Everything seems very fresh and flavorful and it really does taste like home. *Sniff*
author: Cake M.

description:
I second that emotion on the Bailey's Irish Creme scones. It's one of my favorite aperitifs so to find it in scone form, well, how cool is that?

Kate liked the chocolate scone, and even better, tonight she tried the Shepherd's Pie and liked it. Any new food for a six year old that I also really like is, well, devine. Perhaps it's because her first nanny was from Ireland and at the age of two we went there for her wedding.

Oh, and try the Orange soda from Belfast. it's pretty darn good. Different than Orangina and the Mexican Orange sodas and nothing like Crush for sure. 

Next up, brunch at the bar next store to get the full effect :)
author: Dennis S.

description:
The best 'Grab N' Go" in the city.

  The mouth watering fare that flows from such a small eatery is jaw-dropping! This master baker from Belfast uses imported ingredients to create authentic Irish breads. Choose the "Pasties" filled with plenty of meat and veggies, ($4.75) Or Amazing breakfast sandwiches like the Foccacia with bacon, egg, pepper jack, and an interresting buttermilk sauce that melds everything together so nicely. ($5.50) The scones here are very different. Scones?  I don't like scones so lets call these scone cakes. Raisin, plain, blueberry, or chocolate. I loved them all!  Grab five and the're only $1 each!

There is no seating here just 'Grab N' Go'
author: Scott D.

description: I love this place, a party in my mouth, love the chocolate and blueberry scone/biscuits, so moist and tantalizing.  I HEART this place.  And the IRISH accent from the workers.  Go here ASAP.  No joke, I flew from Denver to San Fran just to visit this place.  Go The Richmond, it's yo birthday.. go The Richmond.
author: C S.

description:
This is a great bakery! I've had the Shepard's Pie, some pasties, and the curry. They are all very good. The prices are reasonable and they has a very large selection. They also have delicious custard pies.

However, they do need more people working because they get kind of busy for just the one girl. She is hot though.
author: Troy S.

description:
2 words: HELLA GOOD!
Best blueberry scone around. It's soft and fluffy, not hard and crumbly. They only get better warmed and with a flick of butter.
author: Bluey B.

description: If you're a fan of meaty pies then this is the place to get one.  Both their beef and chicken pies are MEATY and sooo good.  I take them home, heat them up in my oven and have a good time...
author: Emy B.

description:
I believe that this place has the yummiest Irish Soda Bread and my sister swears by their pasties pies (not sure what they are really called) that they heat up for her.

This place is small, but oh so great. You can smell the deliciousness from across the street! 

The staff are great, very friendly and quite helpful. I even bought their tshirt - don't mind being their walking advertisement ;-)

Wonderful little Irish Bakery.  A definite place to go ...
author: Jenny M.

description:
I like this place. It's small and stands out from the myriad of asian pastries/eateries in the Richmond. There's just something really weird about this part of town. You've got the russians, the jews, and the chinese, and then the yummy jumble of ethnic foods all over geary and clement.

This place is way better than going to Starbucks or Peets for your caffeine and pastries.  Their scones are soft and pluffy like biscuits, really good pasties- the chicken curry is my favorite, and their snowballs are like, from the words of Steven T. "just like densed donut holes" with coconut flakes on the outside and jam in between. It's really popular and I personally like it with a hot cup of tea. Prices are fair, parking's a bitch, but everyone seems to park illegally, including me.
author: Miss Pigg y.

description: I had the chocolate chip scone and it was delish! They also have chopped sausage wraps, beef pasties and sandwiches amongst their Irish baked goods.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
OMFG

when i traveled through england and ireland as a student i lived upon fine bakery (and hard cider, but that's another story). light, fluffy, yet moist...it seemed to me bakeries in america were unable to produce a proper scone. and now the search is over. how does john do it? 

this is truly an oasis of fine baking among the desert (no pun intended) all around us. thank goodness i will never again need to contemplate the coagulated sawdust that coffee places like starbucks sell disguised as scones.  

the icing on the cake (no pun intended) is they refuse to use artificial sweeteners like corn syrup so you will not find it in anything they serve. coke in the cooler? sugar. pecan tart? they tell me it has secret ingredients, even the staff are not allowed to know, but no corn syrup. 

delicious. obvious that they actually care about making and serving good food. service was awesome too. free tastes before purchase.
author: Mulberry S.

description: When I moved to the Richmond I was so happy to see all these authentic Russian and Kosher Delis. Then  I came across John Campbells one day and I was in heaven. There breads, scones, and shepards pie is AMAZING! So authentic and delicous they also have flatbreads and great breakfast specialties like the Belfast Bap, stuffed with irish sausage. This place is really great!
author: Sean C.

description:
Oh those scones!  I find excuses to come to the neighborhood just to get them.  I even like the chocolate chip ones, I must confess.

They have nice samples, and the place is authentic.  Staff is personable, although for scones that good, I'd deal with surly help and a crappy store, neither of which would describe John Campbell's.

It's worth saving room for their baked goods, even after getting dim sum at Ton Kiang.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Chocolate + Scones = awesome breakfast. 

Rolled in here after a fun night out and the nice guy behind the counter didn't even seem to care that it was 9 am and I had on party clothes.

Seriously, 5 scones for $5. Your roommates will love you
author: Chrissy L.

description:
Yummy scones - especially the bluberry ones.  I tried the focaccia bread with toppings and they were good too.

Coffee is made to go - so make sure the 38L or 38BX is more than 5-minutes away before going for that.  

Enjoy.
author: Bessie T.

description:
They make Pasties for your tummies - not your boobies -and they are FANTASTICDELICIOUS!!!!

As are the scones and the crusty white bread.
author: Robyn C.

description:
I had a friend telling me that there's this wonderful scone place on Gary and she had bought some to share with me and boy was I hooked on the scone.
I know it's not hard to make scone but boy some people just don't know when to stop kneading. I have since bought the Bailey scone (ok not fantastic), chocolate scone (very good), raisin Scone ( great). All I need is some clotted cream and I'm set!!
author: Andres K.

description:
You dont know what you have until its gone... or you are.
I moved from this area and completely miss the small treats, especially the rhubarb ones... on and the bread... oh and the massive sandwitches which go very well with the bar drinks next door!
And to top it off, alway friendly great service.
author: Brian F.

description:
Breads, breads with meat, pastries, sandwiches, awesome.
Even while I was in here as a first-time customer, there were 2 other people explaining to another first-time customer all about why this place is so good and what they love to order. There is a definite buzz about this place.

Next time: I'll try an open-face sandwich, which looked really good.
author: Jacob and Brianne H.

description:
hot irish construction worker men with sexy accents and tan biceps alert!!
humina hummina wowy wow wow hello.
they flock here to eat their native food maybe. and they bring their hot latino friends along to try their baps.
the pastries, sandwiches, porkpies, breads, cream filled scones, and other goodies are way too cheap for the quality.  as in they could charge twice as much and i wouldn't think twice.
god bless you irish god of sexy men with freckles eating black pudding.
hot man.  i want to smell your armpits.
the food is worth ten stars btw.
author: yayoi s.

description:
I've lived in the outer Richmond for 3 months and I've only just discoved this place. The scones are obscenely good. I never liked them until I tried the Bailey's scone. So delisously decadent...with toasted almonds on top. The breakfast sandwiches? Amazing. 
If you'll excuse me I have to make up for 23 and a half years of not eating scones.
author: Lauren T.

description:
The only thing that could make this any better is a patio where fans of the delicious baked goods could sit and chat about how John Campbell's is the best bakery in the Richmond. I can't believe I've lived in the neighborhood for three years and haven't popped into this bakery until the last month. I now have a difficult time keeping myself from stopping by this friendly spot every single day. I mean that. Every.Single.Day.

I've traveled a few times to Ireland and I don't even think the baked goods there taste as scrumptious as this authentic bakery. I can't think of a better dessert to take to a dinner party than a plate of their small tarts--all of them are delicious, but the raspberry almond stole my heart from the beginning. The scones--oh my--I could go on and on. Try their plain scone (slightly sweet, terribly fluffy and light) with lemon curd and cream at your next afternoon tea at home. The chocolate chip and blueberry scones are at the top of my list, too. 

The last three visits, I've not been able to pass up the healthier sweet potato muffin, maybe the best muffin in town. Made with wheat germ, bran, loads of sweet potato, and not much sugar, these are some of the moistest, most delicious breakfast treats I've ever had. I have to keep myself from buying the jumbo muffin and settle for the regular size. 

Never leave without a chocolate chip cookie, either. I haven't tasted many that are as good as these. 

The customer service is fantastic, and most days you can sample some of the bestsellers, as the kind folks behind the counter enjoy showing off their fare as much as I enjoy eating it! 

Don't miss their daily soup specials, either. This place gives new meaning to split pea soup. And take home a loaf of their soda or brown bread for your next carb fest. What a gem on less-than-quaint Geary Street.
author: Catherine P.

description:
Breakfast next door is Terrible.  The omelette was burnt and Velveeta was substituted for cheddar cheese.  But the black & white pudding were crispy if that is to your liking.  Coffee forgettable.  Really just bar food served by a hungover cook just trying to get through his Sunday.  Not worth the money.
Better to get the scones and soda bread from the bakery next door or grab a Chron and drive out to Louis'.
author: James A.

description:
Absolutely brilliant!

Last week I picked up pasties and sausage rolls and I cannot find the words to describe my pleasure. Definitely as good as the ones I've had in the UK and better than many!

It's not easy to make a great pastie, but Mr. Campbell has done it. I can't wait to stop in again for more treats!
author: Karen S.

description:
Their scones are great for breakfast.
Their pasties (chicken and curry) hit the spot.
The shephard's pie ..... heavy but good.
author: Blu n.

description:
Five stars: This is a bit premature, but went by here today and was literally forced to come inside by the sight of the baskets filled with scones.

Tried the Bailey's Irish Scone and nearly crapped myself with how good this was.  First, it tastes exactly like Bailey's - unreal.  Then it crumbled, so perfect and moist, that I didn't miss buttering it (and don't give me any purest crap b/c finding unsweetened cream in the US is virtually impossible).  Finally, the soft biscuity texture was offset by a crunchy topping of sweetened slivered almonds.

I think I am in love.  Just don't tell Arizmendi that I will be cheating on them periodically...
author: Charla W.

description:
Very good bread and baked goods but for God's Sake $6.25 for brown bread?? It's not very big and what is it about it that justifies the price (I'd love a reply from the owners on this) I've loved brown bread ever since my visit to Ireland years ago. But to the owners/bakers at John Campbell's please re-consider the price of your brown bread! And would you consider stop wrapping it in plastic wrap. It takes the freshness away.

Three stars for price....bordering two stars.
author: Steven P.

description:
Had fabulous baked goodies for brekky today.  I had a beef and veggie pastie and it was delish!  Good size too ($4.75).  

Their scones are so YUMMY even if you don't like scones you have to try these.  They are light and moist, not  like other scones.  They are 5 for $5 or $1.25 each.  I got five... tried all the flavors... plain, choc chip, blueberry and raisin.  I like the blueberry the best.  The others are good too.

They have huge breakfast sandwiches with egg and bacon, etc.  Looked good. $5. Definately next time.  Oh they also have tarts, sausage rolls (meat stuffed in puff pastry), shepard's pie, Irish brown bread and soda bread.

This bakery is small and there is no seating area.
author: Serena H.

description: If it's too early in the day for Guinness (next door), have some coffee and a scone.   Staffed by genuine Irish immigrants!
author: Tom H.

description: I love to come here and shamelessly indulge in fatty carbs. The people behind the counter are super nice and don't give me a judgy face for taking a bite or two before I get out the door, which I appreciate. The other day I had something with chocolate and cherries that I hadn't seen before, but it was like the heavens had blessed me that day. I'm sure it would have tasted amazing heated, but I messily ate it on the bus and regretted not getting another. My only criticism is that the bread tends to get hard throughout the day (duh) so go earlier rather than later, or just heat it. I would definitely recommend this place if you are in the area and like delicious carbs.
author: k h.

description: What a great hidden gem! On a street filled with sushi, dim sum, pho, and thai restaurants, this Irish bakery is a nice change of pace. I stopped in yesterday to grab a half dozen chocolate chip scones for our breakfast. The scones were absolutely delicious - moist, tasty, and oh so fresh! The bakery also carries Irish soda bread, traditional brown bread, and a wide variety of scones.
author: Colleen C.

description: EVERY SINGLE ITEM HERE IS FANTASTIC!!!  This is a gem many people don't know about.  Shephard's Pie is something I hated as a kid, but love now...so good.  All sweet pastries are amazing.  Cookies are so buttery and perfectly baked.  This is a must for bakery lovers
author: Linda C.

description: Walked into this place on a whim after catching a glimpse of their amazingly delicate and tasty looking pasteries items in the front window. Walked in and grabbed a cinnamon sugar english muffin (absolutely perfect with butter) and a chocolate chip scone, both topped off by a warm cup of irish breakfast tea. The latter which was instrumental in lifting the sleepiness and sf fog from my bones (the sugary foods helped to I'm sure)... to top it all off the decor is lovely and green and service personable and excellent. The shop lady and I talked about our various irish family members and roots. And! The irish bar is right next door in case a morning brew is also in order. Nice!
author: Camille B.

description: Not sure what took me so long to find this bakery.  John Campbell serves up a variety of baked goods both savory and sweet, as well as a mix of imported beverages from Ireland.  Don't miss out on the cream filled Scones.  If you're wondering the scones AREN'T the dry crumbly type that you choke on.
author: Jason A.

description:
As a native of Northern Ireland, I went along to John Campbell's having seen the window filled with goodies from back home.

My first visit was yesterday evening and I had the most unbelievably rude experience with the American server. On approaching the bakery, he and his friend were standing outside the bakery smoking and at first glance I thought they were from the pub next door. However, one of them followed my friend and I into the bakery. After asking him for a pastry which I had previously seen in the window, he replied in an incredibly rude tone that they had never stocked such an item.

Feeling that he may be unfamiliar with the name of this basic Irish pastry, I described them to him after which he was still unfamiliar with it but didn't offer any kind of similar alternative.

I said, "Oh, I must have been mistaken", to which he replied in an extremely patronising and vicious manner, "yes, I think you are!"

All the while his equally threatening and unfriendly mate was circling behind us making faces.

Perhaps the management should make better staffing choices or at least offer a training session in basic courtesy and customer service. This guy is definitely not their best PR move!
author: Girseach S.

description:
I absolutely love the chocolate cherry bread, and the soda bread. The latter especially takes me back to my times of living in Dublin. Sarah is delightful behind the counter and especially enthusiastic about the bakery's goods.

One request: I know you have three thriving bakeries in San Francisco. It would be great if you could open a bakery in Oakland -- either in Temescal or the Uptown arts district in downtown Oakland. You'd give Bakesale Betty a run for its money, and I know you'd be very successful.
author: Ari L.

description: Their chocolate chip cones are light, fluffy and not too sweet.  Even better- they are only $6 for 6 scones!  Even better still- I LOVE bakeries that are open past dinner time.  10PM on weekdays- what troopers!
author: Judy K.

description:
I love this place. I end up buying more than I need. The have a nice selection of authentic and not so authentic treats. Friendly service!

WARNING! Do not visit this bakery when you are overly hungry.
author: Edward K.

description:
warning: do not come here on an empty stomach because you may leave with half the store!

great irish bakery with many baked goods of the emerald isle!  i love their brown bread.  they have selections of different shepherd's pies and pasties.  loads of scones to choose from, and many other sweet treats!
author: Sheri N.

description:
Pasties fit for the gods...their curry and chicken pasty ($4.75) could be the best pasty I have ever had (though it's hard to find pasties so my pasty experiences have been few and far between...I did make it to BJ Bulls for pasties before they closed though).  They're made by John Campbell who holds the "Order of Master Baker from Belfast and the City and Guilds Bakery Certificate."  The chicken curry is superb.  I could eat it over rice.  It's surprisingly spicy and complex.  The chicken cubes are tender and the filling includes peas, carrots, and red bell peppers.  The crust is flaky and thin.  The chicken & vegetable pasty is similar but mild and just like chicken pot pie (which I adore) but in pasty form.  The filling is creamy and rich.  So good.  They also have a beef & vegetable pasty which is very good but my least favorite.  It is ground beef and not much else (some carrots and peas).  Right now there are three pasty varieties, I'm hoping for more in the future - like beef & curry would be brilliant, steak, and lamb too.  

The scones are great too but the pasties are out of this world.  The plain round scone is buttery (but not too much so) and golden on top.  It holds its shape pretty well (rather than being a crumbly scone).  I think it could be a tad more tender. Reminds me of a sweeter buttermilk biscuit.

The Irish brown bread ($5) is fantastic.  Nutty, multi-grained, chewy.  It screams for butter and some strong coffee.

The coffee (Jeremiah's Pick) is strong but has a bitter, overly acidic aftertaste.  They have lattes and Celtic iced coffee as well.  And the employees  (owners?) have Irish accents.  Very cute.  

I'm excited to try the shepherd's pie ($6), breakfast sandwich (Belfast Bap), sausage rolls ($2.95), custard tarts, cream buns, fresh cream filled scones and the Irish bread (soda bread, potato bread, batch bread).  They also sell bagged Irish potato chips (or crisps) by Tayto.

They've been open for four months and I don't think they're that well known yet.  I predict long lines in the future.  It isn't cheap but the ingredients are imported and the quality makes it worth the paying more for.  

On weekends (10 AM - 3 PM) they have a brunch menu served next door at the Blarney Stone Pub, and it includes the traditional Irish breakfast, Irish sausage, Irish bacon, and Irish pudding.

Such a brilliant idea...Irish pubs are a dime a dozen in SF but how many Irish bakeries are there?  One.  John Campbell's.  Why didn't someone think of this before?   John Campbell, I love you.

Update (2/27):  They no longer make lattes and espresso drinks.  And it's cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description: Scones are out of this world... Fresh, great variety of breads, free (delicious) samples and friendly service. One word: YUM!
author: Tony M.

description:
I noticed this bakery not so long ago when sitting on the express bus heading downtown.  I rarely go to new places in my neighborhood... but in the spirit of trying new things, I am checking out all things new.  A friend of mine mentioned this place to me and she said it was great. She lied to me... it is TO DIE FOR!!!!  I wanted to try some of the goodies that were mentioned here, but they were out... I kinda made it there a bit after 2pm on a Sunday, but never fear... I got some good stuff... 

Soda Bread: Delicious... about 5 bucks... worth every penny!
A bread with almond paste in it... I missed the name... but it is topped with almond slivers, There are raisins and I think cherries?  Well... whatever is in it... it cost about $9 and it was worth every single penny!!!! Then we ordered one of the beef pasties and can I just say.... it is the best ever!!!  It was warmed by the very friendly girl at the counter... (I think we had a sighting of John himself... he came out to talk to a lady who came asking for him. )  We ate that delicious beef pastie like it was the last thing on earth!  Filled with LOTS of ground beef. & veggies.. seasoned so delicious that I was so sad I was sharing... this was $5 and worth it too!  All in all we spent about $19... sounds like a lot... but man... it is sooooooo good that it is worth it... seriously!  Next I will try the Irish sodas... they are $3.00, but I have heard great things about them.  I can't wait to come back!  What a wonderful and welcomed addition to my Richmond District Neighborhood!
author: Amelia M.

description: I stumbled upon this place while doing a job around the corner and what a find I went 2 days in a row...Onlt tried the coffee and a blueberry scone I will be back though
author: Kim R.

description:
loves these guys!! :) 

awesome food and stellar customer service! they'll make suggestions for you about the food and breads that they have and they always have fantastic samples available. they also  have other candies and treats that i haven't seen for sale in the states. 

great pricing too. the only thing to know is to bring cash! :)
author: Sherah M.

description:
haven't tried enough of their products to give 5 stars quite yet, but everything in the display case looks quite promising.

the lady behind the counter has an irish accent. so pretty.... anyways.

(1) chicken and veggie pastie: the best part of this pastie was the buttery, flakey, flavorful outside crust casing of the innards. if you decide to take it home cold and toast it at home, the pastie fills your home with a nice warm aroma of yumminess! the chicken vegetable and potato tasted as it should. actually the chicken was of good quality not dry (mostly dark meat, good) but man... that flakey crust was SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO GOOD, leaves a girl dreaming for seconds. ($5)

(2) snowball ($2) this can be found in the front self serve window of the store. i'm eating it as i type this right now, and goes well with my spot of tea. :D 

scone like texture of the dough and a small layer of fruit jam. my favorite part of this snowball should be obvious. the outside crust of coconut!!!! SOOOOOOOOO GOOD!!!!! you know what would be even more awesome? if they make these snowballs in to little bite size snowballs. 

i'll be back.....

garlic bread, guiness bread, tarts.... def will be back for more.
author: Irene C.

description: Blueberry scones, irish soda bread, snowballs, and all other sweets are all tasty. I knew it. But wait until you try one of those savory meaty little pastries...Jason and I were walking out of the store while breaking the juice dripping meat pocket, we burned our fingers and tongues but we were so happy!
author: Yuchi C.

description: The raison scones and shortbread cookies are amazing, I can't believe I just discovered this place! I have only tried the sweet baked goods, but will be back to try their savory options and breads. I also really like that there is always a variety of things to sample on the counter and the service is friendly. And, they only accept cash.
author: Nicole E.

description:
This place is great! 
If it weren't for my hardness about not eating a lot of sugar and refined starch, I'd eat everything all the time.
I tried a plain scone and their little $0.25 apricot shortbread cookies--so cheap!--and both were delicious. The shortbread cookie was really outstanding. The girl at the counter was also nice.
author: Kan L.

description: I've been here twice.  This morning went here with Marty and Shannon.  The GF and I got an apple puff and a chocolate scone, Shannon is the Irish one and got something Irish-ish, Marty wanted a cheeseburger and got a beef filled pastry.  It was all delicious.
author: Alex R.

description: I've lived two blocks from this place for 9 months and I FINALLY checked it out a couple weeks ago. It's absolutely amazing - they fit such a variety of delicious pastries, cookies, and sandwiches into such a tiny space. I'm addicted.
author: Vanessa F.

description: I live very close to this bakery and was really happy when they first opened as it was really good. But lately things are not fresh. The last time I went there I got two pieces of foccacia, $2.50 a piece, and when I got home they were so hard and old that we couldn't even eat it. When I returned them, the girl at the counter gave me back $3.00 and told me that she had undercharged me before...  did she realize she was selling  stale stuff? Not going back!
author: Buena M.

description: Wow, they have pumpkin tarts! Which is like mini pumpkin pies! Their pecan pie is soo good. Their almond scone has changed though! They no longer put a sugar on top so now it is just very plain..
author: Janet Z.

description: Love this bakery.  The scones are so light and fluffy and not too sweet;  the meat pies are great and the prices are reasonable too.
author: lucy ..

description:
update and -1 star for continual staff turnover and telling me they never made something just because they are too new to know about it. boy am I cranky. 

********************************************************************************

right in my sweet spot -- owner on the prem, even got the 'apostrophe-s" in the name. every morning they're full of freshly-baked scones, loaves of bread, and an increasing array of sandwiches.  A great "only-in-SF" find. 
hint: try the sausage rolls.
author: jim b.

description:
I thought I'd died and gone to heaven. 
Fantastic brown soda bread. Scrumptious rhubarb tarts. Thrilling raspberry tarts. Buttery, melt -in-your mouth shortbreads with or without raspberry or apricot jam. And flavourful chicken curry pasties. And that was just the first visit. I had to be dragged away before I did myself an injury from trying to carry away too many delights. 
Anyone will love their scones or biscuits but I urge the uninitiated to try their griddle cakes and other tradtional Irish fare for new thrills.
author: Holly E.

description:
so many things to love about john campbell's irish bakery:

1) the best curry chicken pastie i've ever tasted, if not one of the best pastries i've ever had in my life. so damn good it's scary. the filling is robust and spicy, bursting with peas and carrots and chicken and taters. the crust is purrrrfect. doughy and soft, gives right away under pressure yet is hefty enough to be the perfect vehicle for the stuffing goodness.

2) amazing shepherd's pie. the beefy layer beneath the fluffy mattress of mashed potatoes is well done. flavorful and good for sharing.

3) this may sound ignorant, but i do love getting an aural dose of irish brogue with my food. makes me smile.

4) the decor is charming - think lots of dark wood and pine green. 

5) i hate scones, but i like the ones here. they look like biscuits and don't taste like drywall. 

6) plenty of other goodies to try!
author: jennifer y.

description:
I was enticed into this joint by the positive yelp reviews.  All I can say is, if you really want delicious baked goods, keep on walking.  This Irish bakery is not up to snuff.

First, the "raisin scones" look like they would sit in your stomach expanding for 3 days like elvish lembas bread.  We shied away from these based on the appearance, but ventured to try the tarts, one rhubarb, and one "mince" (spiced apple).  The rhubarb was not sweetened enough and had a tasteless dough (what are they using to make this? clearly not butter).  The mince tart was inedible, due mostly to its off-putting spice mixture.  We had actually wandered in there wanting dessert, but left hungry.  

Pros: Nice interior decorating, friendly staff

Cons: The food
author: Jade P.

description: I keep a couple of sausage rolls, and chicken curry pasties on hand.  They are my sure-fire cure for a hangover.
author: Charlie S.

description: My giirlfriend and I discovered this bakery over the weekend! talk about gourmet!!!!  this bakery screams gourmet!!!!!  everything is delicious!!!! forget diet!!! You must check this place out. Sarah is so passionate about everything in this bakery! She will have you smelling their fresh baked breads, sampling their delicious flaky scones, she can sell anything out of there with her passion! the chocolate eclairs are the best! Stop on by and see for yourself.
author: erika c.

description:
Fantastic Irish brown bread----my dream come true to actually have this 2 blocks away! The scones are yummy and the service is excellent with a side of humor.  I will try it all--I will!

Update:  As of 04/04/08, they now have mushroom shepherd's pie,  and yesterday I got both a chocolate mousse tart and a chocolate mousse eclair.  All are delicious.  Not to mention their soups are a delight!
author: leigh m.

description: while i was waiting for a table for dim sum, decided to run to the bank. on the way there this irish bakery caught my eye and i couldn't resist spoiling my dim sum appetite. bought a blueberry scone which was soft, fluffy and full of sweet blueberry flavor - i loved it! the bread i sampled there was also tasty. i'll be back
author: Diana B.

description: Died and gone to heaven.  The first time I walked into John Campbell's, I spent 30 minutes just looking at all of the fresh, wonderful food.  I then went to the ATM machine.  Twice.  Love this place.  I go often and get loaded up for myself and my family up north.  This is the first place I have found where the ingredients are true to form and really fresh.  Thank you for opening up!
author: Bronagh H.

description:
ok.  imagine this.  you walk in and some teenage boy with a hecka strong irish accent starts to describe everything in the case and you get very excited about all the fresh whipped cream on the raspberry tarts, but you're really there for breakfast and so you order a belfast bap. 

and then you have a heart attack because its overflowing with eggs, bacon, cheese, and sausage. 

later, when you're arteries clear a little bit you look forward to bringing your British mother in law.
author: Nora B.

description: So, I made another trip in to try the pastie- not bad. But the highlight was the cream filled blueberry scone. Can we say Heaven? I made sure to get up early the next day to pick up the 5 for $5 regular scones. They had just come out of the oven and I had to try desperately to keep myself from eating them all on the bus ride to work. Mmmm..good. I was hesitant to share my tasty treats (being an only child and all) but I did and my office mates loved them as much as I did.
author: Lindsey G.

description: The Irish Soda Bread rocks!  Someday I'll try the other stuff ... when I can eat it on the spot or soon after purchase.
author: Debbie T.

description: Had the new Corned Beef sandwich yesterday.  It was really good but the woman behind the counter could have been a little nicer.
author: Jeffrey M.

description:
The blueberry scones filled with cream are really really really good.!! I usually shy away from cream, but couldn't help taking a bite.  And, then I could not stop. The cream was light and fluffy and really added to the yummy scone. 

I also like the Shepherds pie, raspberry tart, and beef rolls. 

Check this place out!!
author: vernice l.

description: I just stumbled upon this little gem in my neighborhood about a half an hour ago. I feel like I won the lottery. I'm having a chicken curry pastie as I write this and it is sooooooo good. Also, got a few rhubarb tarts, and corned beef sandwich that looks amazing, a shepard's pie and a cream-filled scone that I ate on my way home for less than $20. I'm so happy right now, I feel like I want to jump in the air and kick my feet together side-ways.
author: Neile R.

description: I've been twice now and had good luck both times! The scone was freat and the previously mentioned Belfast Bap is unique and yummy. This is one of those places where you could eat anything they make. Nothing fancy just fresh and tasty. I think I'll go for a sausage roll next time. They also have great Brown Bread which my Irish friends say reminds them of the old sod. That's all you need to know!
author: Jim M.

description: Not bad.  1st time I've ever seen an Irish Bakery in the outer Richmond. Seems like it's not too settled in yet.  Love the scones!  Be back for more reviews.
author: Christi S.

description: This place opened up just in time for my semi annual trek back home, the workers are super nice and conversive. The great pastries that they have one up the crap they sell at the starbucks for triple the price down the street and taste a hellova lot  better. This hidden lil gem is a keeper that will stand the test of time I believe.
author: Ray H.

description:
oh . . . my . . .  goodness, it's so delicious and they are the nicest people ever!!!

the soda bread is delish, the pasties make you feel all warm inside which is good for a rainy day, and don't even get me started on the sweets, because i can't decide what i like the best apple puffs or the shortbread tea cookies or is it the sweet potato bran muffin? why???? i haven't had the shepard's pie or various soups yet, but if what i have had is anything to go by the i am already a fan.

but above all i have never had scones that were so light and cake-like and i have learned how irate my friends can get when i don't bring them to our monthly brunch. usually when i have them from anywhere else, they are dry and could break a window. maybe this is what we americans are used to because i see people eating those doorstops all of the time. but we should demand better-we should demand john campbells!!! 

as liz lemon would say, "i want to go to there".
author: Wendolyn A.

description: Had the filling and tasty chicken curry pie and a blueberry scone. Will come back to this charming carry-out store for more next time I'm in the Richmond :) Friendly staff.
author: Patricia M.

description: This is my first Yelp review, so bear with me. . . I LOVE John Campbell's! This place opened last week - I found out about it through the www.misterarcher.com review and I have honestly gone back everyday. I may be a sucker for tasters (and they regularly have six different tasters out) so I may be slightly biased, but everything in this place is amazing. The apple puffs are heavenly, the griddle bread is ridiculously doughy and delicious, and the potato bread is like nothing I've ever tasted before and I can't understand why this isn't a dietary staple. Seriously, you could even pass it off as a vegetable (potatoes. . . anyone?). Anyway, I've tried everything - even the mince pie (which tastes like a double stuffed gourmet fig newton). You can't go wrong- unless you don't go!
author: Andrea H.

description: This place is wonderful! The curried chicken pastie is out of this world, and the owner is so polite. I love his Irish accent! I will definitely be back. The only reason that it gets 4 stars instead of 5 is because the coffee is merely ok, not great. But take that with a grain of salt. I used to be a barista, so I'm a coffee snob. Give this bakery a try!
author: David H.

description: Tasty scones, and at 5 for $5, how can you go wrong?  That is a seriously cheap scone, ladies and gentlemen!  I can't wait to try some of the other baked items at this joint.  Prepare yourself:  If you order a bap, you won't need to eat for the rest of the day!
author: robyn s.

description: I had no idea what to expect from an Irish bakery, but you know I am game for anything. I had already eaten so I couldn't partake of the hot food items and opted for a chocolate moose eclair. OMG. To die for. I don't even like sweets! So good. So people def got a kick out of me eating it. Nice service. Next time I am going to pick up some items, stuff them in a cooler and journey back to the east bay to pig out. Eclair was 3.50, super good smooth rich creamy moose. I love you Irish people and bakery!
author: Jocelyn F.

description: A friend of mine (a GREAT friend of mine now) brought me a chocolate chip scone from this place.  It's like eating a cloud with chocolate chips in it.  I'm in heaven!!! :)
author: Stacey W.

description: It all looks great in the cases and very pleasant staff, but the only time I bought several things to take home and try, there was mold on the scones and bread and that scared me and I through it all out which was kind of ignorant and childish.  I must go back and ask why or if that was an isolated instance.  I'm impressed that we now have an Irish Bakery to complement all the Irish Pubs we host.  More after I go back and give a fair shot at.
author: Stu S.

description: Best ever.  Friendly service. Beef pasties never fail to please my guests.  LOVE this place!!
author: MidnightMunchies X.

description:
an honest business when there are so few in the world (read: US)
but, honestly, I truly madly do love this place
great coffee, scones, and people
I bought the 5 for 5 scones and the guy behind the counter asked me which kinds I didn't get and definitely just added them to my bag
now we will be best friends, obviously

PS
i live around the corner.. be jealous
author: Josie A.

description: I love this place. Get the scones, even if you're not a scone person. These are what scones should be - light, fluffy, rich, studded with currants. The shortbread is yummy too.  And give the baps a try for sandwiches...  I'm so excited this is in the hood!
author: cindy m.

description: What a great local bakery.  I've tried their foccacia bread which is heavenly when fresh.  The scones are light and a bit fluffy and just melt in your mouth.  And the shortbread cookies are just damn so buttery.  For a bakery there aren't that many choices but everything they offer is quality.
author: Ben M.

description: WOW THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!!!!!!!! The food is amazingly good and the people who work there are really nice. They all remember you whenever you come. I havent been here many times, but the times I hae it was really really really delicious. The only thng is that there is no were to eat there, so you should take it to go.
author: Nikita K.

description: I literally have had just about everything that they have with the exception of some of the fancier breads. This place is amazingly delicious. I have very few places that I say this about but...if I could I would eat from there every day and not get sick of the options. I have noticed they are getting a little more crowded when I go in there...I hope they are around for a long time. My favorites you may ask...Tea Cookies, Choc Chip Scones, Rhubarb Crumble, and focacchia(sp?) I wish I could eat now... I am ready to cry....talk amongst your self's
author: John D.

description: The yummiest Irish brown bread! The guy behind the counter recommended it as even better than the soda bread! Boyfriend had some kind of meat pie thing and a sausage thing (he can't remember the names) and enjoyed it thoroughly. Prices are a little high ($5 for brown bread), but we didn't feel a bit guilty after being so satisfied. Boyfriend has never raved about a bakery before, much less dropped $12 at one and felt good about it. This is damn good.
author: Thlel Yan D.

description: The new gem of the Richmond.  This place serves up an excellent cup of coffee, frothy and yummy.  The bap's are a big bang for your buck.  I have yet to try the brunch!  A nice change from the blah of starbucks.
author: Amber N.

description: Heads up if you want fresh-today baked goods---Filmore St. opens @ 7am, but they don't get their delivery till between 8-9.  I made a special trip this morning @7am only to find a half stocked store; no chocolate chip scones and everything day old.  Disappointed.  I'll go back again or just go to the source on Geary when I've over there.
author: Janet R.

description: The best bakery in the world. Shepard's pie and sausage roll are amazing, as is EVERYTHING else. You can't go wrong here.
author: Dre D.

description: I stumbled across this Irish bakery after a mediocre lunch at Ton Kiang.  What a find!  It more than made up for my lunch.  The scones are incredible - soft and delicious.  Plus, they had about 5 different things to sample on the counter, and all were excellent.  A little pricey, but worth it.
author: Hazel H.

description: Yummy scones and foccacia sandwiches.  We will definitely be going back - 5 scones for 5 dollars !  They were so flaky and subtly sweet.  Im not making any more for myself- Great find in the Richmond!
author: cece S.

description: This little bakery feels like something you might encounter in a page of Joyce's Ulysses - although the novel is set in Dublin and the founder of this magic place is from Belfast. Topological issues aside, what really matters is that these guys make outstanding soda bread with raisins, shortbread cookies, and other delicious goods. For a bread freak like me, this is nirvana. Make sure you try the blueberry scones and the brown bread. Warning: they are both highly addictive. All the goods are homemade and, as you can imagine, the color green is pervasive. Look for the leprechaun hiding behind the counter. By the way, there is no seating, people, this is a take-out only bakery. Grab the goods and head to Baker Beach. Leopold Bloom would have loved it.
author: Matt B.

description: The Irish soda bread and brown bread are very tasty.  I had a Belfast Bap as well which was delicious, although a little overwhelming for what I planned to be a "light" lunch (oops).
author: Jeff K.

description: I thought Irish coffee was that drink one orders at an Irish pub until I came here one morning and they had quite the variety of Irish coffees to help me wake up. Ok, I know this is not very helpful... but the little tart looking pastries filled with almond paste and jelly...wow. No moderation when I see them, that's my confession.
author: Florentina D.

description:
I tried out John Campbell's Irish bakery this morning.  It was excellent, and the service was really friendly.  Furthermore, the prices were entirely reasonable.  The place was clean, etc, etc.

The menu is as follows:

Breads - 
Irish Soda Bread
Brown Bread
Irish Crusty Bread
Guinness Bread
Garlic and Pecorino Cheese Bread
Pesto and Sundried Tomato Bread
Potato Bread
Chocolate Cherry Bread

Scones - 
Blueberry
Raisin
Chocolate Chip
Bailey's Irish Cream
Plain

Tarts -
Almond Raspberry
Mince
Custard

Breakfast Sandwiches - 
Belfast Bap
Focaccia Sandwich
Corned Beef and Cabbage

Pasties - 
Chicken Curry
Chicken Veggie
Beef

Soups - 
Chicken Curry
Split Pea
Cream of Mushroom

We tried the blueberry scones, the belfast bap, and also got a sausage roll.  The blueberry scones were wonderful, and only a dollar a piece.  The belfast bap was enough to serve two people.  We saved the sausage roll for later.  The bread from the belfast bap is also available separately.  Furthermore, they had bowls of samples of the different types of scones and the focaccia bread.  

I would highly recommend this bakery.
author: M R.

description: Fed up with lines out the door at Tartine?  There aren't any tables, but John Campbell's Irish Bakery will satisfy sweet and savory cravings.  The scones are pasties are wonderful, and the Guinness bread with cranberries and walnuts rocks.   The Irish brown bread, though, is phenomenal.  Crusty on the outside, soft on the inside and just a little sweet.   Grab some on a foggy Sunday morning and have a strong cup of tea.
author: Bea A.

description: I love coming here. The scones are fantastic, the coffee is strong, and the staff is always very nice.
author: Cora Z.

description: The Curry Chicken Shephard's Pie is one of the best meals I have ever had.  It's spicy, but not too much heat and the chicken was tender and the mashed potatoes were fluffy.  Excellent.  The Chocolate Scones were amazing too!
author: Kaius G.

description: We were out to lunch on a sunny Tuesday afternoon and a friend convinced me to check out an amazing Irish bakery down the street.  I've lived in Ireland and England and was looking for some buttery deliciousness.  Cute little place with all the things I know and love.  I got some cookies and a few tarts.  I tried to get some of the bakewell tarts, as the almond raspberry tarts are called across the pond, and she snapped that she didn't know what I was talking about...fair enough.  I would've been okay with that if she had a little bit of customer service in her attitude but I think she left it at home that day. She threw everything into a bag and when I got home, my tarts were squished together...a $10.00 ball of mushy appley pastry. Not a good experience, maybe if I am in the neighborhood I will be back to give it another try.
author: Sheila K.

description: an irish friend of mine brought me here today, and i was like a kid in a candy shop!  yummy scones, SODA BREAD (!!!), shortbread, shepard's pie....omg i couldn't stop gasping with delight!  parking might be a b*tch, but it's sooooo worth it!
author: Sally T.

description: We had the almond raspberry tart - so amazing! It's got an exquisite marzipan taste to it to, so good. Would go back again just for that. Everything else we got was good too- a chocolate eclair with dark chocolate and REAL whipped cream, and also two other kinds of $0.25 cookies. Not to mention the dollar milk. Good find.
author: Vegg E.

description: Good food, but Irish? This bakery is full of British, Italian and French food! And Campbell is not an Irish name...I guess soda bread is Irish?Despite the misleading name, it's actually a damn fine bakery!!
author: Gazza B.

description: So far I've only bought the chocolate chip and the raspberry scones, but they're always delicious and a very good buy at $1.50.  I think they recently changed their weekend opening hour to 8:00 am, but that's still early enough for me to stop by for by hiking/biking breakfast.
author: David C.

description:
New coffee now being served on the weekend of July 28.  This is the best coffee I have ever had in the continental US, without doubt.  I have had 1 or 2 cups in Kona that were probably as good...which tells you how good this coffee is.  I had 1 dark roast with cream and 1 medium roast with cream and it actually tasted like maybe they foamed the cream because it was very silky, very airy, almost like cafe au lait.  The dark roast of the coffee really cuts through the cream, very earth and very rich but not too overbearing.

Like the other postings here, the food is terrific too.  But go for the coffee...the coffee...if you'll excuse me, I have to cut this short because I am going back for another one now...
author: Ian O.

description: John Campbell's  Shepherds pies are extremely satisfying comfort foods. I have tried the traditional, mushroom, and curry pies and they are all delicious. Be sure to check out the curry options at the bakery, they are amazing. The scones are awesome! And the vegetarian pea soup has a perfect blend of flavors. The rosemary in the soup is genius. Campbell's also gets bonus points for  the hot redhead who works the afternoon shift. He's a cutie.
author: Lindsey L.

description: This is my new favorite place.  I've been craving scones since I came back from London and couldn't find anything that tasted remotely home-made. Until now!  I love that the scones aren't too eggy or too sweet.  Between my friends and me, we tried almost everything.  All the cookies, scones, tarts and  other pastries were amazing.  The shepherd's pie was really good.  I've had some really good and really bad shepherds pie, and wasn't disappointed by this one.  The texture and the flavor of the beef was really good.   The only reason I gave it only 4 stars was because the only soup I liked was the potato and leek.  The other soups were disappointing and all of them were too cold. Other than that, this place is amazing!
author: S B.

description: Wow  this place was amazing,  It was so nice and warm inside very cozy and the girl even had an Irish accent. Like others recommended I tried the blueberry scone and it was as good as all the reviews said it was. I also got a loaf of the Guinness bread and it was also just perfect. I will go back to this store for sure!
author: MICHELLE G.

description: Amazing, delicious, and affordable.  The Shepherd's Pie is incredible, and great to pick up before work in the morning.  Everything I have ever tried here has been super delicious!
author: Chelsea M.

description: remind me to stop coming here. tired of paying full price for day-old, or multi-day old,  scones, that they mix in with the fresh basket. the scone i just bought this MORNING is dry and hard. two of the other bakeries have closed, this is no way to keep the remaining one open.
author: steve w.

description: Strolling around the Marina with the wife and youngster in tow, happened upon this little gem. Cool young hipster behind the counter, very helpful. Ended up with several chocolate-almond tarts and a shepherds pie. Both excellent. Will definitely stop by again when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Brad B.

description: by far the cream filled scones are to die for... no doubt... go try them now....
author: Frank M.

description: 4.5 stars easily. the half star off is for the prices, which aren't exorbitant, but are still a little painful on the wallet. i came in today at about 9:30, and they didn't have sheperd's pie yet! it's alright though because i was shooting for the belfast bap sandwich. irish bacon, sausage, egg, melted cheese, all in a belfast bap roll for 6.00. portions are definitely filling, but i wish it had been a dollar cheaper. the service was very friendly as i had never had any irish baked goods before so i was very inquisitive, and the lady behind the counter was more than willing to help me out. she even warmed up my sandwich and gave me some traditional irish brown sauce on the side. i also sampled their irish brown bread, irish raisin-studded soda bread, and their breakfast in bread. everything tasted so fresh and delicious. the bread was savory, the meat was salty and filling, and the place smelled and looked like heaven. will be back for the sheperd's pie soon!
author: Danny C.

description: Oh no, I don't believe this. After finally finding a place that sells scones that taste almost authentic now the John cambell bakery has added a small amount of cinamon to the raisin scone!!! why I ask you why? I love cinnamon, but an English raisin scone should not include cinnamon in the ingredients. Otherwise it'll taste like everything else in San Francisco. Either full of garlic or full of cinnamon.  It's like the French bakeries. Having grown up in France, I am used to eating pastry that does not have cinnamon. But here, even the French stuff, most of them, have added cinnamon. So disappointing.
author: farinaz A.

description: I don't know who the hell John Campbell is, but his eponymous bakery is one of the best in the city. My faves: round loaves of dense brown bread, fluffy scones studded with currants, and baskets full of "snowballs". Snowballs are two half-globes of cake held together with rasberry jam and covered with chocolate and coconut. They also have savory pasties, I recommend the curried chicken. Overall prices are a little steep, but I've never regretted buying, or eating, anything from JC's.
author: Jemima P.

description: Hand's down- best bread in the city!  I have yet to try one I don't love.  Personal favs- the brown bread, pesto and sun dried tomato bread (especially nice toasted!) and the cherry chocolate bread!  They also do some amazing almond sweets:-) Yay for the Irish!
author: Heather M.

description: Though I live only a few blocks away, it took me many months to make it in here. However, once I had my first taste of their baked goods, I knew I would be coming back on a regular basis. Their scones (raisin or chocolate chip) are nice and flaky. The pasties (no, not that kind of pasty--the hand-held pot-pie kind) are perfectly cooked, with a golden exterior and a nice ratio of vegetables and/or meat to sauce on the interior. I especially recommend the chicken curry pasty. I don't normally think spicy when I think of Irish food, but the curry gives it a nice kick to the traditional, modestly seasoned pasty. Finally, their garlic cheese bread gave me a true food-gasm. It was so good that it took all of my willpower to keep me from eating the whole loaf right there on the street. It was great on its own, with my picnic lunch, and with the frittata and cherry tomatoes I had for dinner. YUM!
author: Katie I.

description: I can't get enough of Campbell's.   Whenever I go to work from my girlfriend's house, which is happening more and more, I always stop here for breakfast.  They have delicious coffee and such an assortment of delectable morning treats that I can't stop myself.  Seriously, I can't stop myself.  I have been eating Belfast Baps like they are going out of style.  What, you might be thinking, is a Belfast Bap?  Well, it's delicious.  SUPER delicious.  And it contains egg, cheese, sausage, and bacon on some delicious bread.  Yeah.  uh-huh.  It's like that.  One half of it would be enough to suffice for a decent breakfast.  In fact, most folks I know can only eat half because it is so large and delicious and they also pay attention to things like cholesterol and their weight.  But I could give a f*ck(I can't stand it when people do this sort of thing with cuss words but I feel like I have to) about those things, especially when I see the sign.  In fact, I am eating one right now as I type with one hand.  This review is taking me forever and actually keeping me form fully enjoying this morning's breakfast so I must get back to what is more important than telling you about it.
author: Charley B.

description: ah yes...soda bread like my nan mary (from sligo) used to make, and pasties to rival anything from cornwall. every time i bite into one of their treats it's like time-travelling. totally authentic fare that's more like home-made than motorway cafe. the staff is super sweet as well, and if you happen to not know what anything is (i guess they're used to people not knowing what baps are), then you'll get a quick education in irish baked goods.  really ace place, and thank g*d they're in the richmond and not the sunset ;)
author: roz A.

description: You know when Homer Simpson thinks about something delicious and his eyes roll over in his head and his tongue hangs out the side of his mouth and he kinda goes, "Grullllaaaaggghhhh..." and drool drips down his chin?  That's basically how I feel about the apple puffs and sugar cookies and chicken veggie pasties and shepherd's pie at John Campbell's.  And other stuff there too.  I just wish they still made soup.
author: Shane O.

description:
my cousin dragged me here to try the scones, as they are her favorites. 
perhaps not THE BEST scones i've ever eaten... but they are pretty darn close! a very nice texture - much more moist, soft, and cake-like than your typical scone. tried the blueberry, choc chip, bailey's irish cream, and the plain. ok, so we didn't try the plain yet, but i'm sure it's great too (totally envisioning it as the base for a spectacular strawberry shortcake - oh baby!) the blueberry and choc chip are sooooooo moist, MMMMMM! the bailey's is a little more on the dry side, but has the most delicious taste! probably my favorite of the 3 i ate.
before picking out our scones, we drooled for quite a few moments over the sandwiches, tarts, pasties, and cream-filled scones in the display case. after we left, we drooled over the list of breads in the menu. 
essentially - we will be back! very. very. verrrrrrrrrrry delicious!
author: Aletheia W.

description: They have the best scones you can find in San Francisco.   They are so soft, and have great flavor.  They also have delicious cookies, breakfast bread, and tarts.  The workers have always been helpful to me, and they always have samples.  One time I went with a friend and my husband, and they let us have a whole tart for a sample.  This is a great place to stock up on quick breakfasts for the week, or bring your mom and dad when they visit you.
author: Chastidy R.

description: The scones are delicious but I discovered the chocolate cherry kirsch soda bread - OMIGOSH. It is to die for! I had it when it was fresh from the oven and still warm. I could have eaten the whole loaf in one sitting. The owner was very sweet and gave my daughter some cookies while I was looking around. Will definitely go back when we're in the area.
author: Keromi K.

description: most amazing scones i've ever tasted in my life! so moist and delicious. tried the blueberry one and the chocolate chip. most amazing thing to wake up to. can't wait to come back and try the bailey's one!!!
author: N. M.

description: Sure, John Campbell's food is good, but you can get good food almost anywhere in S.F... the difference is the Irish experience and the great service but only after 2 pm.  What brought me back is the service and conversation. Recently the bakery had extended their hours to stay open until 10:00 P.M.  which is perfect for a procrastinators (like me). But the smartest thing the bakery EVER did was put that hilarious, skinny, black haired guy behind the counter. I went in for a Bap the other night after work and he had me rolling! After a long day at work listening to my annoying co-workers the only thing that could ease my troubled mind is a Bap and a joke from that guy. When I was there, people were coming over from the bar next door to buy food just because that guy was so funny. One ambitious morning I decided to wake early and hit J.C.'s for a pre-work Bap thinking maybe some laughter before work would help me get through the day! But the funny guy, the best part of J.C.'s wasn't working. I bought the Bap, but after eating, I still missed the uplifting fun I usually had when patroning JC's. Short version: Go to J.C.'s  in the evening, when that skinny, funny guy is working, or don't go there at all.
author: ben b.

description: great place.  The scones and brown bread are excellent.  I drive from NOPA every weekend to buy bread and check out the pastries.   Best bakery I've found in the city in the last 5 years.
author: michael s.

description: if you haven't had the cherry & chocolate bread, you need to.  just get it. take a big bite.   And yeah, afterwards you'll want to write a review of this place as well.
author: A K.

description: I really didn't know what to expect from an Irish bakery, never having been to one in the past. But the reviews were positive, and I'm always up for adventure, so we gave it a go. It was the great surprise of my vacation. Two words: mincemeat tarts. Holy cow! Tangy and sweet, but not cloying, with a delicate crust. Unbelievably good...I want one every day. The Guinness bread was also a delight, dry with walnuts and cranberries. Probably would have been better toasted with a bit of butter, but being in a hotel, we couldn't find out. The veggie pastie was flaky and filled with curry and vegetables, not overly spicy, but warming. I can imagine it would make a great lunch on a wintry day. I wasn't as into the apple tart as the micnemeat...it was a bit too sweet. But the man behind the counter was really patient and helpful, and even threw in a few extra tarts. If I could give a 4.5 I would, taking off only for a lack of seating. My pastie was heated for me to eat it, but I had to enjoy in the car. I will be back, Mr. John Campbell. Have some mincemeat waiting for me.
author: lisa s.

description: john campbell's has single-handedly changed my opinion of scones.  they are moist and taste like a scone/biscuit hybrid.
author: why l.
